Very nice, simple gameplay. Really enjoyable.

Excellent mechanic/theme matchup. Gameplay was addictive and enjoyable. The simplicity of the graphic design complimented the mechanic well. Plus it didn't crash, which makes it better than many I've rated so far! Well done.
Simple and addictive. Is lacking a bit of substance but its fun to play!
Yeah, this is really nice.  That game mechanic's fantastic.
Yay, glad this is being so well received. I'm still hacking on it, so don't be surprised if there's a Super Duper Thwackswinger in the near future...
Neat gameplay idea, i on the other hand didnt like the control that much.
I found it extremely difficult to grab the rock i wanted. and then after that i couldnt work out why it breaks sometimes and not others, i thought it was force at first but then a soft hit breaks.
It's random, actually. I think of it as some being harder than others. (And I just implemented five different control styles for the sequel...)
Quite a fun game. Enjoyed it a lot.
Nice mechanics! As others have said, a bit more polish and variety would make the game even more playable.
I like the idea, but I found it hard to play.
Straightforward but fun gameplay. Quite difficult to fire out the grappling hook accurately though.

description:
This was supposed to be the story of an unarmed protagonist trapped in a crumbling metropolis, one of the last survivors in a war against the machines, trying to make his way to the last enclave of human resistance...
I ran out of time and was too tired last night to finish this in time for the jam (it was originally a compo entry, but I'd bitten off more than I could chew).
All is not lost, fortunately - while doing this game, I learned a lot, and I like the idea enough that I plan to do a high-res remake in the near future.
Source is included; you'll need Allegro 4.2, 4.3 or 4.4 to build it, and it should work on pretty much any platform.  The .exe is statically linked and should not require any additional DLLs.
A cautionary note: please don't base your opinion of my skills on the art or coding style - due to the short deadline, a -lot- of shortcuts were taken and there is no error checking whatsoever (so moving any of the assets will likely make it crash).
author: ｂｒｏ.ｋｅｎ.ｌｉｎｋ
title: They've Come For Me (unfinished)

Update: fixed the truncated mapfile from the initial upload that broke maps from 6 onwards

title: Sporg
comments: Linux users can play with a recent version of pygame, just run src/sporg.py

Moving along walls could use some "sliding", got stuck in the wall sometimes... Most of the levels I could do without using the enemies as weapons, but overall the game is interesting, albeit a tad slow...
Looks an awful lot like the game Oxyd, only way slow to mov the ball around.

Wow the marble really does look a lot like Oxyd. I hadn't seen Oxyd before, but was inspired by a lot of amiga games (particularly psygnosis games), by which I mean I tried (quite badly) to emulate the style. I totally agree that the stickiness on collisions is a real pain, and the game should be a little faster paced. The limitation of 48 hours, eh?
Doesn't seem to run under wine and apparently requires PyGame 1.9.
I'll give it a try sometime after I reboot into Windows.
Sam, did you get a mixer pre_init related error?
Getting stuck on walls was irritating.
Would have liked to collide based on my actual shape, not a larger rectangle, but that is not a big complaint. Decent puzzles with the theme used on some levels. Fun, if a little slow.
Nicely done for a first time entry! A fun game - even though it had me cursing the hit detection when walls that I thought would cover me didn't!

description:
SpaceFreak is hungry!
Guide a stray martian to safety. Kick evil space blobs at SpaceFreak to slow him down.
You will probably be digested.
author: DeathBySnail
title: SpaceFreak Snack
comments: I found the jump sound to be a bit annoying. The main issue I had was that the jumps were always the same height (as far as I could tell, anyway) which made it a little too difficult to actually land on enemies.

This has potential, but it suffers from the lack of any sense of speed and the high, floaty jumps taking too much of your precious time. It seems to pretty much come down to luck with the enemy placement.

I think the basic idea of this has a lot of potential, but it really needs a lot of gameplay polish (everything needed to be faster, and more gravity would have helped a lot). It ended up being really hard to aim or get away from the big bad.

I concur with Last, the fixed jump height made it hard to maintain a rhythm when it came to landing on enemies, so I am going to have to knock off a star for that one.  With some tweaking, this could be quite playable.

Same issues as everyone above... and the game is a bit unforgiven... I had a sequence of 4 guys in a row, and then just one bad jump, got stuck and got digested... what I mean is that the game should see into the immediate success and not punish the player so much... just an idea, of course... :)
It does feel a but slow though.
One time I got stuck on a too steep slope at the begining.
Really like the squeaky run sound.
I actually really liked this game. If you make a post compo version I would love to see variable jump height and some different obstacles or ways to slow the monster down.

Absolutely AWESOME!!!! At first I thought it was just way too hard and I was going to mark it down and not even bother to comment... But something about it kept me playing. 15 was the best I could manage, but something about this game is just great... Make it easier to keep away from the big guy and add some other factor into it to keep it slightly varied and this could be one that people play for hours! This is just one step away from greatness.
Oof, yeah that jump feels awkward, but I think this is a promising idea that mostly just needs some control over the jump arc.

I liked the sense of being chased by an enemy that I can't directly face. This is the best thing your game has to offer and you should definitively expand on it! The rest IMHO is a matter of tweaking.

author: Darkhogg
title: Space Recycler
comments: I really wanted to like this game cause it oozes fun. Sadly the control of the ship feels very 'indirect'. It also has a nice amount of variety in the enemies which I liked.
I agree with Jhelle. This game is OK but could be great with better control. It annoyed me not being able to accellerate backwards, because it takes a while to turn around.
It's a shame because concept, graphics, presentation etc. are good.

The controls felt very sluggish which made it less fun. The graphics were simple but were consistent and had a polished feel which was good. With a bit more polish and variety in the gameplay this could have been a solid entry.
Better controls: angular motion should be faster and with more friction. Straight motion should be faster and with less friction. This would make it easier to aim and dodge.

It was too hard to kill enemies. The regular bullets were too slow and not very powerful. Also, if you shot at an enemy with some debris but missed, you would lose all the debris. There should be less penalty for missing when shooting debris (perhaps by not shooting all of it at once, or having a wider spread angle)
Faster game pace in general. If everything moved a bit faster and the controls were more fluid this could have been a fun game.
The slow turning really hurt this one

oh wow, i didn't even see that bug. it took one line of code to fix. bluh, stupid leftover code. oh well. thanks!
Keep up the good work!  All it needs is an intro to explain what to do and some sound.

An enjoyable game. I kept wanting to press up to jump though, and its annoying to wait for a miss thrown decoy to disappear (I kept pressing the wrong button)
Really enjoyed this puzzley game, but some simple sound effects would have made it. Would like to see the sort of levels you could make using the mechanic with a bit more time.
Liked seeing the concept art in your journal.
I like this idea a lot. Too bad it is so short :(

description:
This game was inspired by the "Land of the Dead" movie, where a zombie starts to get smart and command the others against humans.
Objectives & Game Mechanics
Kill all people by turning them into zombies (just touch them) or making the shooters hit them by mistake.
People who became zombies will help you to kill more people (you turn your ENEMIES into your WEAPONS :P). Their normal behavior is AI controlled, but you can give commands to them.
Game Controls
Arrow Keys: Move
Shift: Commands your nearby allies to come close to you
Alt: Commands your nearby allies to go away from you
Ctrl: Commands your nearby allies to move as you wish (control them with the arrow keys)
Z: Commands your nearby allies to disperse
X: Commands your nearby allies to attack the person closest to you
* This game has background music and sound effects. If you're using Java Web Start and any of them seems broken to you, try downloading the game zip file instead. *
Development Details
Language: Java
Engine: JGame
IDE: NetBeans
Images: Gimp
SFX: sfxr
BGM: Wolfram Tones

title: Revenge of the Living Dead

too hard to find the humans in the massive level
links not working for me, will check back tomorrow.
as already posted the level is HUGE. almost impossible to find all humans before loosing interest. besides to that. well done.

Great work.  The JAM version is waaaay better, the radar arrows are essential.  This could be made into a compelling RTS with a bit more detail.  Especially if the zombies could have faster movement.

Tks! Yes I was thinking about a RTS version too!! Just put different zombie types, like an Ahmed zombie that explodes... and more human types... and make humans build shelters (so you can destroy them too).

The game worked fine for me. My main complaint is that I don't see much strategic depth in this.

title: Man Cannon
comments: Wow, that was pretty hectic. Controls took a moment to fully comprehend (I though IJKL was a separate control scheme). but once I got the hang of it I was having a lot of fun! good job!
Really hectic! I liked it a lot, nicely done.
I liked how you had to "build up" on enemies so you could destroy the tanks. It was an interesting concept.
Good stuff! Bullets were occasionally hard to keep track of, and the tank's hitbox could stand to be a bit smaller, but I keep obsessively replaying it so you've clearly done something right.
Nice concept, very hectic and chaotic!
The controls are quite hard to master (maybe you could aim with the mouse?)
The advances way too fast. You should give people a chance to learn the game before spawning the chaotic hordes of enemies :D
Starts too fast (hordes of enemies before you even got used to the controles) but besides to that a great idea. sadly no music but worth playing.
The game is pretty average and is hard. But has tons of room for improvement, keep it up!
Great work for 10 hours, although I feel that this would have been more awsome as a side or vertical scroller - that way you could arrange the enemies into waves with very little extra work.

description:
As a hacker you need to take over servers, to use their powers to hack more servers. Dunno if that fits the theme.
I'm happy I finished and I'm some kind of proud of the voice-acting / music /gfx stuff :D
thanks 4 watching
Bugfixes applied. Updated Binary and Source available.
author: madpew
title: Hacking4Dummies
comments: The game is well done, although it's bitch hard... : Don't think it suits the theme, though, but even so... it was fun playing! :)
System.InvalidOperationException: Die Sequenz enthÃ¤lt mehrere Ã¼bereinstimmende Elemente.

Fun! I suck at Mastermind but it stayed interesting. Some different layouts for the route might have been nice.
I commend your effort but I didn't feel the fun factor here. Audio was very well done though and I liked the server names :)
Really liked this game, though it did remind me a bit of the plumbing from bioshock. Audio was excellent as well.

description:
Yay my first ActionScript thingie :)
but, to the point...
Your farm has been overridden by some strange space zombie chickens. Destroy their nests and free your homeland!!!
But....
Since you're just a chick, you cannot attack chicken, so you have to gather eggs which contain them. When you're armed with eggs, you can distract chickens by throwing other chickens at them and steal their nests!!!
You can also destroy chicken that you threw automatically by placing self-destrucion device in them. And it's all done automagically!
So go, and get rid of them chickens with chickens!
Controls:
Arrows - move
1-6 - select chicken
Z - jump (hold to stick your head to the ceiling)
SPACE - throw chicken
BACKSPACE - kill chickens you threw
EDIT: I just found out that level design makes it impossible to beat the game. You can collect only 12 out of 14 nests, but since nothing happens in the end, i guess it doesn't matter.
author: Sos
title: Fight Chickens With Chickens
comments: I liked this one. The animation of feet spinning in a wheel like that was pretty hilarious. The idea of sticking to ceilings like that was also pretty cool! I almost beat it, but I couldn't get the last two nests (they were the ones up on the top-left).
I love the sticking to ceilings thing!  It's a shame it's not completable.
the big one made my day :D
Best title ever.  I was a bit confused at first as two why I was killing the chickens, but then I realized I could capture their nests.
The controls where hard for me.  sticky then.. jumping then AAaahhh.. oppss.... shot my chicken...nooooo... it's attacking me!!!! Grrr.....
Very complete entry and lots of game play.
Cool game. The ceiling sticking took a bit of getting used to but it was an interesting way of moving about a level once figured out.
The only frustrating thing about the game was that it was unpredictable which way nearby fighting chickens would move and/or when one would pop out when capturing a nest.
Well, the graphics and sound are nice, but I couldn't figure out how to even get past some of the first obstacles because my character couldn't jump very high.
I loved the sticking to the roof mechanism - i wonder if this feature originated as a physics bug but you decided to make it a gameplay element :P

description:
Please spend 30 seconds reading the instructions!  You can then read the tips after you've played a bit, if you like.
I really wanted to do something other than "throw enemies at enemies" or "take control of enemies", etc.
Then it occurred to me that the enemies don't have to be the player's enemies.  So I based the game on picking up symbols of things, matching pairs of mutual enemies (e.g., democrats and republicans), and using the contention between these natural enemies to power your gun.
I only implemented one type of (pretty lame) bad guy for you to shoot, so the actual shooty gameplay isn't as compelling as I'd like.  I also spent about half my time in Photoshop, since I'm a coder, not an artist, and I was very slow at making the icons.
Done in Flash, with FlashPunk.  Sfxr used for sound effects.
author: Martoon
title: Ennameez
comments: innovation... yep, there's something i haven't seen before... done quite well actually
fun-wise, it's pretty run-of-the-mill, but it works somehow
theme is a very interesting interpretation, and i'm giving you 5 stars for uniqueness
audio is there and it works
humour is there and while it's an amusing concept you totally cocked up the fact that the fish is a christian symbol as well as the cross, plus i find the reference not that amusing
overall, i recommend looking into this game for general interest
community effort... quite extensive, you've gone so far as to show what food you ate so i think you basically went all the way (other than a time lapse) so 5 stars for you

description:
The basic idea of the game is really simple, you can't shoot and have to make the turrets kill each other, or themselves.
You move your ship with your mouse, when you move your ship near a turret it will shoot at you, then you can dodge the bullet or reflect it with your shield. If the bullet hits a turret it will do damage to the turret.
When you have your shield raises you receive no damage, but the shield is drained while in use, and regenerates slowly when unused. You raise your shield by holding the left mouse button.
Once there is only one turret alive you release the megabomb and win the level.
Hope you like it.

description:
You are a peaceful, un-armed UFO, but this planet isn't having it.  Protect your self from them using you Deflector Beam.

title: Deflector Beam
comments: is it possible to provide an exe that can be run without an installer? installers suck for this compo.

A nice attempt, but in need of a lot of tweaking before it shows its full potential. Would be nice to see some sounds and maybe some explosions, and the beam would be nicer if it moved faster and gave you more control over bouncing the bullets.
Still, good try, and a very appetising journal! :P
@ sfernald - The installer helps with all the XNA prerequisites and so is the easiest.  It's also a minimal install.  But, I'll see what I can do.
@alistar - Thanks.  I completely agree with your assessment.  Unfortunately, I lost too much time dealing with some physic engine issues.

I'll give it a try sometime after I've rebooted into Windows.

Welcome to LudumDare, I hope you enter again!

Okay guys, I put up a zip that should let you play without the installer.

description:
Dead End inc.
You can also get it from github if you want, http://github.com/PhilCK/LD18.
I wanted to do more with the sounds but simply ran out of time/energy. This was my first LD, and it was fun, certainly wont be my last (unless of course there isn't another one :)
Game Synopsis:
The daily grind of a dead end job has you resenting them! THEM! The middle management. DAMN THEM! DAMN THEM TO HELL! They are the ENEMY! Oh look a Zombie attack, I'll throw some managers at them.
Use an endless supply of middle managers to fight back an endless onslaught of zombies storming your building.
Min Requirements
OSX 10.5
Win XP
Notes:
The readme has some minor bugs in it, if you find any please feel free to let me know.
MBP 13 Bug fixed via new version of Gosu (Thanks Jlnr)
big thanks to jlnr
and of course made with libgosu.org :)
author: Basic
title: Dead End inc.
comments: The difficulty curve felt a little abrupt. One moment I was knocking single zombies off the building, when suddenly there was an entire swarm. Other than that, it was a neat little game (although I was a little sad that I couldn't take out zombies that were still walking around with a properly-timed manager).
"although I was a little sad that I couldn't take out zombies that were still walking around with a properly-timed manager"
Damn it - I turned it off for some reason or other then forgot to turn it back on.
Very cool, have the same complaints as TheLastBanana...
Cool idea, nice graphics and a good implementation (despite the "hit zombies on the ground"-thing)
:) somebody linked a fed ex ad to me about a guy who doesn't want to do work thats beneath him cos his has an MBA.
Simple, neat looking, fun and nice humor :). Good work
On a side note the MBP 13 bug is fixed thanks to an update from libgosu
I really liked the style of the game, especially the little chat bubble in the title scene and spat out by panicked managers. Slick!

description:
This is my first time participating in Ludum Dare and hence I of course estimated time requirements badly. I live and learn though!

Anyway I hope you enjoy the game, I'd like to belive that I managed to show my concept!
(Note: In case this is not the text you remember it's because my entry for unknown reason decided to vanish for a while!)

description:
CHASSIS COMMANDER!
Marooned on an unknown planet!
CHASSIS COMMANDER!
His only weapon, a hoverbike with a malfunctioning weapon!
CHASSIS COMMANDER!
Besieged by a million unstoppable robots!
CHASSIS COMMANDER! (you should be imagining this with a significant amount of reverb btw, go back to the beginning and start again if you're not)
Can he use the robots to repair his vehicle? Can he muster up enough firepower to defeat them all? Can he learn how to use the over-100 unique weapons that he can cobble together from compressed robot parts? Can he survive this horrible onslaught?!
CHASSIS COMMANDER!
Play it today!
------
If you liked this, check out my other projects at http://www.mandible.net .
Game sourcecode is available in the package as human-readable .lua files, engine sourcecode is at http://github.com/zorbathut/glorp .
author: zorbathut
title: Chassis Commander
comments: Very good job, found it entertaining...
Wish there were less robots in the beginning, so I could understand better what are the different upgrades, what's their effect, etc...
But really good job on the weapon variations!

I thought it was pretty fun. Sometimes I got a notice that the ammo I had selected was unusable, and I wasn't really sure what I could do about that, so maybe adding onto that message what is required to use the ammo would be good. Otherwise I quite liked it. I see the link to your source code there, but you might want to include it as an official link labelled "source" just for the sake of clarity.
Gives me a weird complaint about not having OpenGL 2.0 and exits.  I'd try to figure out what the problem is, but I can't seem to find your source.
Will give it a go sometime after I reboot into Windows.
I really like the idea of combining the weapon modifiers!  It seemed like sucking them up was usually the best way to kill them though...
Sam, I'm guessing the problem is that you don't have OpenGL 2.0 :) Try grabbing one of the OpenGL version checkers online, see what it says.

The source link is at the bottom of the blurb, right above the screenshots. That said, I wouldn't recommend that anyone besides me try to build it - you'll need to go through a not-insignificant amount of pain, although I'll help people through if they really really want to.
Some more variation in the robot graphics would make it better.

comments: beautiful choice of interpretation!  I'm sure I woke up the rest of the house laughing!  Physics were a little tough to play with though

Haha, I love the little mouse silhouettes in the chopper.
Wonderfully daft! I particularly like the "miaow" noise :P

I always thought that picking up and throwing was the obvious interpretation of the theme, but using a physics-controlled robot arm from a helicopter is something I would never have thought of. Nice :D
Definitely the funniest game I've played, even if I never really got the hang of throwing the cats.
Love it!  You can rack up the score if you get a lot of cats in one area, but then you also risk getting PUMMELED by yarn balls!
Good interpretation of the theme. I also liked the low poly cat model and simple background. Normally I'm not a fan of Unity games but this one won me over. :)

description:

author: Ricket
title: Birds of Prey
comments: I don't think you intended to make me load org.inh.JavaError.
Also, how big is this wrt filesize?
How about giving a link to a webstart version? You have a lot more chances of it working for everyone. At least you would gain full java 1.6 support not only from update 10 and newer.

Love it. Was following this one as you wrote it (I'm @voxel on twitter) lots of fun, meets the theme, just not a lot to it. But I'll be damned if I can stop flinging birds around. Some tighter collision detection would be awesome though
I like your bird drawings but the collision seems to be off.
Simple but very amusing little game. =P Was fun to randomly fling the birds around.

GreaseMonkey: No, JavaError loads if you have an old version of Java (or maybe something like IcedTea on Linux). But I didn't get around to actually making it, so it just has an error I guess. The filesize of my JAR file is only around 800kb, but the JOGL libraries are some few megabytes (I'm not exactly sure, and it depends on what OS you have). And the whole time Java is downloading this, it just shows a white screen as if nothing is happening (at least in my experience). So that's why I say to be patient and wait to be sure that the download finished and what you think is an error, really is an error.

ruben01: The JNLP file doesn't seem to work but you can try it: http://insertnamehere.org/birdsofprey/applet.jnlp - my stance is that perhaps if you have an old Java you should update; besides missing features, there have also been a lot of security concerns over the last bunch of minor versions.

author: moop
title: AstroVax
comments: I couldn't quite figure out how to make the powerups work. I got some sort of shield by sucking up the yellow things, and my bullets turned blue/red when I sucked up groups of enemies. But they didn't seem to give my any sort of advantage. Perhaps it was a score thing?
Overall, it's a finished game, and playable, so congratulations on your first Ludum Dare.

You were correct with the groups thing. Groups of 3 gave a power up of the same elemental type as the group (fire, water, earth). I'd intended to have more combinations but time constraints and trying to avoid distracting attention from the shooter aspects prevented it.

Activating one of the special bullet types or the shield gave a score bonus, also fire bullets instantly killed water enemies and water bullets instantly killed fire enemies. Killing enemies outright in this way also gave a score bonus. Likewise using the shield to smash enemies while invulnerable gave a bonus.

I thought I'd leave the specifics of the scoring to be discovered but looking back that was a mistake. Most likely in this sort of event where there are a multitude of games to play they need to be immediately accessible or people will lose interest and move on.

The graphics are nice and retro, creating a retro effect without it seeming like you're just using low-rent graphics, which is always good.  The core mechanic is nice, but I never felt like I was in danger or really needed to do anything.   I don't get why the game ended.

I had the same problem as surrealix; I couldnt figure out why I should suck up the enemies other than to clear them from the screen or get a shield. In particular, I couldn't tell that the enemies were elemental, they just looked like different colours. I dont like this fake low resolution effect at all. Low resolution graphics were a necessity in the retro era due to hardware constraings, not a stylistic choice, and your choice of faking a 320x200 resolution played against you here because I had no idea they were fire/earth/water. Just thought they were different colours.

On the up side, once you figure out that there is a strategy to deciding which enemies to use as weapons and how to do it properly, the game gains an additional layer of depth. The game is also quite close to my idea of the theme, so 4 stars there.

Mike, nice game, is that your own custom flash engine?

Grisly! Pretty fun, though. The controls were a little awkward, though - I felt squished using the arrow keys and mouse at the same time, since I'm right-handed.
I got stuck in the ground while playing =<
Fun game although I keep getting the cannon stuck in the floor.
Hi guys, thanks for all the comments. Not sure why eveyone keeps getting stuck in the floor :( I have provided the source link in the entry im not sure why the link isnt showing up at the top.
For those interested the source is here --> www.mikecann.co.uk/DumpingGround/ld/18/05/LudumDare18.zip
And no, no engine was used, just coding from scratch, maybe there was a utils class or two I used.
Not sure why eveyone is getting stuck in the floor, I cant get that to happen.. hmmm
Nice game! The graphics are great and it works well. It's a bit too easy but oddly relaxing.

Good job on this one... The graphics are amazing... only complaint is that on my screen, I could see offscreen stuff, which was very distracting, always thought an enemy was comming lower than expected, only to have it come high on the screen...
@Covenant im not sure what you mean you could see the side.. can you provide a screenshot of that mate so i can better understand whats going on?
sweet game, is a little easy tho, i had about 60 ammo left at end
@Jhelle thanks :) only 40 hours, a few more hours and it would be even more polished! Alas!
Hmm... is the ammo supposed to fall *into* the ground and thus become impossible to pick up? I can't catch most of it because of the slow pace of the canon... My highest score is 4.

@stqn yes the giblets are supposed to fall and then become part of the ground, admitedly they should bounce abit first giving you time to pick them up. I guess thats a bug that needs to be fixed at some point!

That's rather fun. I quite liked the way I felt I sometimes had to judge whether it was better to pick up a gib, or let it become part of the landscape to help me get over an obstacle. Until I realised I could just shoot the ground to remove obstacles.
Awesome game, really cool style too!
Just to let people know, I have now made a timelapse and gameplay video. They are also linked at the top of the post.

Ah, I see now... First I didn't know I could jump, which helps... but anyway the canon moves at least twice slower on my computer than in your video. I think the enemies go at about the same speed though.
Fun game - the Bastatron animation was great and the graphics were outstanding overall.   Never once got stuck in the floor =)
@stqn ye its quite a CPU intensive game, I didnt get time to test it on a lower spec machine than my quad Q6600 :P
If I decide to release this game after the competition is over ill definitely have to optimize it abit!
But if you used the elapsed time between two frames to compute the canon movements, it should go at the same speed on all machines, right? (Pentium-M 1.6 GHz under Linux here.)
Anyway, for a two days game it's pretty polished. Well done.

@stqn ye I used the frame delta, so im not entirely sure whats going on. There is also the issue that the giblets can generate terrain and DONT collide with the player, so that could result in the player getting stuck if the giblet joins the terrain exactly where the player is.
I spose the easy solution to it all is to decrement the yposition of the player each frame until no collision occurs :P
@someone Glad you liked it :) Ye audio is definately my weak point, i have no idea how to make music :P

This game is wonderful. Simple and effective, cute and macabre at the same time. Wonderful. The sounds are great, I love the rolling animation of the tank, and the whole thing has so much personality.
Using enemies as a source of ammo isn't massively innovative in itself, but this game takes a wonderfully literal take on that concept. It's grosstastic :D

description:
Giant monsters are attacking your city! Hypnotise them and send them to fight each other. Different monsters are good at beating different other monsters, so you need to choose who you hypnotise strategically.
Made in Flash using ActionScript 3.0
--- HOW TO PLAY ---
Use the mouse to move around the landscape. Use the mouse wheel to zoom in and out.
When you have 100% energy (bar on the left), click on "Mind Control" and click on a monster to hypnotise it. The cursor will change to red rings when you do this.
When a monster is on your side it will change colour.
Click on a monster on your side and the cursor will turn to red. Then click on a square to tell it to go there, or on an enemy monster to tell it to attack it.
Monsters work in a Rock/Paper/Scissors fashion:
GODZILLA beats TURTLE
TURTLE beats DRAGON
DRAGON beats GODZILLA
When the control centre (centremost building) is destroyed the game ends.
--- NOTES ON JAM VERSION ---
The Jam version is mostly identical, but tidies up the movement to make it less wobbly and more intuitive. It also has more obvious/usable instructions and cursor animations to make it easier to tell how to play.
author: Alistair Aitcheson
title: Mind Control Monster Mash
comments: It's a little hard to manipulate the monsters when the screen tries to scroll as you're moving around.  Otherwise, great idea!

Congratulations for finishing! Unfortunately I'm not able to play this to its fullest, because it runs quite slowly on my computer. This is a fairly slow machine, hopefully the game will run better for most.

The instructions don't stay on the screen long enough to read, and the game proceeds to start while I'm still trying to read them. Even after three attempts plus rereading what you have on the submission page, I couldn't figure out how to actually get one monster to attack another. Gave up after about 5 minutes of clicking everything I could see. It looks like a straightforward theme mechanic, just a little confusing on the implementation. I like the art style though.
Thanks very much for the feedback. I've added instructions to the submissions page. Sorry you couldn't get the hang of it and I hope you have better luck now!
The reason the in-game instructions are so poor is because it was getting close to the deadline when I added them. My bad ^^;

Just to let you know I've added a tightened-up version for the Jam. It's still rough around the edges, but the controls and interface have been improved. It's more clear what's going on, and the camera doesn't zoom around everywhere anymore!

I don't think I am very good at this game, a lot to manage, and I tend to keep scrolling the screen when I want to click the Mind Control button.  Would be nice if it was based on left click/right click or something.
I had a difficult time actually clicking on the duders and getting them to go where I wanted them. I'm not sure if it was by design or not, but I didn't enjoy that part. It was spot on, thematically.
Control scheme isn't great. There's really no reason to have to click on a "mind control" button: there is only ever one action you want to perform on any given monster (brainwash or give orders).

description:
Retro-styled platformer/puzzle where the main character has the ability to temporarily control the enemy robots. Certain robots have abilities that can be put into use, other times controlling the 'bots is simply to get out of tight squeezes. Be careful when you decide to drop your mine and take over a 'bot because you're completely vulnerable while doing so.. other 'bots might come along and pick you off. Most of the level design was the last two hours, so it's a bit iffy. I'm curious if it's even possible to get through the eight levels. Click where you want to move to, closer the better. Double click to drop the mine in your current location, double click to remove it from anywhere.
Apparently some people have experienced really slow animation. I cannot account for it, since it runs fine on my 7-year old XP box and my 5-yr old laptop. It won't ever run in Internet Explorer, you guys.. Okay, well, maybe IE9.
Part of the plan for this game was to do something totally cross-platform with HTML/Javascript, and ideally this sort of thing will run on an iPad or N900. I have only tested it in Firefox, Chrome and Opera and it seems to run well.
Developed in Linux with GIMP, Gedit, etc. Had to dust off my old WinXP box to run an ancient copy of Reason to do the music (the box of which I'll still need to try out everyone else's stuff!!) Still nothing comparable for Linux yet, but very close. Converted to MP3 && Ogg with Audacity.
You can download the "Windows version" and play it locally or just simply play it online through the web link. The "source" tarball doesn't include the audio files which makes for a much smaller file. Anyway, have fun. This be my first LD. -quoj@hoolikon.com
author: quoj
title: Man And Robot
comments: It's INCREDIBLY slow on both firefox and opera.
Nice work, very hard to play and get what is going on...

Took a few tries to figure out that I was supposed to move the robots out of the way without killing myself. The "mine" in my mind was supposed to destroy them, not start remote-controlling them. Other than that, great work, a lot of fun to play!
Runs a bit too fast here, on Firefox... Doesn't work on IE at all...
The Window is also too small on my TV (I play stuff on the TV, 1920x1080, so it was a bit hard to see the characters). Good exploration of mechanics!

Hmm.. I thought I had worked out the timing code right but apparently not. It runs just a *tad* bit slow on my 5-year-old Toshiba laptop, so I just figured that was it hitting the wall with calculations... <shrug> Glad it's running too fast on *someone*'s system. :)
Oh I see. I forgot to do the animation based on the timer. (bl[i].dx = dirs[d].x * MONSTER_SPEED) Fail! Needs to be multiplied by the inverse of the time since last frame, I believe. Sorry guys!

I love the retro gamboy style visuals.  Gameplay is a little hard to grasp.  I still haven't finished the first level but I did manage to collect all the money bags.  Also I like the fact that it requires only mouse input but movement controls are a little cumbersome.
This game is not intended for track pads!
looks fun, but it runs very slow on my machine. I'm running Windows XP SP3 with Firefox. Tried in IE and it didn't seem to run.
The visuals are really cool and I love the music. But I didn't get the controls, as they all went by very slowly in the opening sequence. Could you put them in the description?
There's probably great stuff here as the concept sounds really interesting, but for now I'll just rate what I can (graphics and audio).
I can't seem to figure out how to get past the first level... I did get all the money bags.
I really like the graphics and music, too bad there's no sound! Nice polish too (title screen, animations, tutorial - even if it's a bit slow).
Works fine here in Firefox under Linux (maybe that's because I'm using a 5-year old laptop too ;)).

description:
Arrow keys to move and jump. Land on enemies, pull them around and force them into the ground to make them shoot each other.
Infinite arcade gameplay, try to get a high score before you perish.
Post mortem: For once I focused mainly on gameplay design. Graphics remained in the placeholder stage, and there was no complex technical code that distracted me. I did however do a bunch of other real-life things during the compo, so actual time spent was probably less than 10 hours. Sketched on various slightly different ideas before I really started working on this one. I'm fairly happy with it, though I somewhat regret not doing proper graphics. Remake perhaps?
author: DrPetter
title: Kanbran
comments: Fun, Innovative and faithful to the theme. You did well!

Neat idea. This is pretty fun. I think it's probably a bit counterintuitive that steering them into the ground doesn't work unless the initial jump was timed right. I wonder if that could be remedied by making it clearer that they're countering our motion? This feels pretty polished given the time constraints. Nice work.
I love it, it's really original and fun!
Graphics are not so bad though, your placeholder graphics are better than my final ones -.-

Great classic console feel, like a super contra-type game on the boss stage.  I noticed what wasn't there because the game was so clean: text.  Most games have some kinda other text on the screen identifying which is score, health, level, etc.  It made sense once I started playing, but that's the one thing I noticed right away.  Other than that, just adding 'intro' and 'game over' screens and this starts to really become a console game.
This is a really neat idea, and the graphics and music are great.  Once I'd figured out the controls though, it felt like the difficulty curve was a little shallow?
well done. even the placeholder gfx is good. nothing more to say.

Seemed a little slow going but once I got to four enemies on screen it became more fun. I felt like I wanted a little bit more to be happening but it was a decent game. There was a nice tension when your health got low to dodging the enemy bullets so as to get the health drop.
A little frustratingly slow early on, but very fun once you get past that.  Needs audio badly!

This was pretty fun, the first entry which I might actually keep on my HD and play in the future. Pinning an enemy to the ground so that they shoot upwards and hit other enemies is a unique take on the theme.
I normally dont like faux-ega-style graphics, but the animation of the little dude was pretty good so I had to give you 4 for graphics. I hope he didnt take too much of your 10 hours.
Audio was just a single tune repeating over and over, so I cant give many stars there im afraid, but at least it was present.
Really nice mechanic. The steering part is one of my favorites. I can only guess the backstory here, but the simple artwork really alludes to something with an epic feel to it.

A very frustrating experience. Why are they so resistant? Normal fire seems to do nothing and even the vertical firing takes a painfully long time to kill them. Also the music would have really needed a longer loop or a way to turn it off ;)
Still for a 10 hours game it's a nice.

description:
The was made in 2 hours as a warmup for the compo.
"Isaiah Mustafa - The man your game could smell like" was based on the theme of the same name, which was sadly downvoted into oblivion :(
Collect red old spice boxes while avoiding the green "double rainbow body wash" ones to improve your smell quality to 100%, the game will then be DIAMONDS.
author: The man your game could smell like
title: Isaiah Mustafa

description:
The aim of the game is to trick the enemy into killing themselves and each other using the Illusion based skills of the character.
The first spell creates a decoy version of yourself. If the enemy sees this decoy it will think it's you and begin firing. The bullets will go straight through, hopefully killing any enemies on the opposite side.
The second illusion tricks the enemy into thinking a pit (the black tiles) is a perfectly walkable tile. It will then either randomly wander into it, or walk across it while trying to chase you. Falling to his doom.
The third illusion is an upgrade to the standard decoy. Any bullet hitting this decoy will bounce back towards the attacker.
Also, at any point you can turn yourself into a rock. If the enemy does not see you do this, it may just walk straight past you, giving you a chance to get out of harms way.
Also. You have a hat. So do the enemy, but yours is better.
- Controls
- In-Game
WASD movement
Left-Click - Select/Cast illusions
Right-Click - Cancel casting.
Space - Don your awesome rock based disguise.
- Menu
WS - Cycle options
Space - Select
Requires the VC++ 2010 Redistrobutable. Sorry about that.
http://www.microsoft.com/downloads/details.aspx?FamilyID=a7b7a05e-6de6-4d3a-a423-37bf0912db84&displaylang=en
Next time I'll use something more cross-platform. =]
author: sinalta
title: Illusion
comments: I really love the idea. it's a shame i can beat every level simply by conjuring up the reflect bullets image.
Played through all 3 levels and really enjoyed it though.
I liked the idea, but you really can beat everything with the third illusion.
I could definitely see this working well as a puzzle-type game - maybe the different spells are limited to a certain number of uses per level?
really rad. as the others said, you can beat everything with just bullet reflection, so i exclusively used 1&2. lining up an illusion so that they kill each other is the best thing.
the pit thing feels really random though. they kind of just wander into it whenever, it's kind of hard to induce them to actively follow you

description:
Hi!
This is my entry for LD18!
Made with C++, ClanLib, Paint.Net, Inkscape and Fruityloops!
You play a sole survivor on a ship, with only your tractor beam active. You need to collect 3 energy cores in order to fix your warp drive and go... HOME.
Hope you like it - Windows only I'm afraid.
Thanks! It was a great LD!
Thanks,
Daniel :-)
EDIT: fixed music not looping bug - didn't touch anything else.. :-)
author: zdanielz
title: HOME
comments: Game crashed while playing. It was fun though.
Thanks! I'll try to fix as many bugs as I can before voting starts..

Things fly around too fast for me! The tractor beam works well, but I can't react fast enough to use it effectively. Also I need an arrow pointing to the nearest energy core or something, because I have no idea where I'm going.
The music was good. Did you make it yourself?
Things are fast because it is fun! :-) Maybe I should have tweaked it a bit more... I agree about the arrow, it was on my to do list, but I had no time..
And yes, I made the music my self, of course!
Love the atmosphere and graphics style! It's gorgeous. Sorry about technical problems with the sound (sfx would be greatly welcome) but you did well with the music. Controls could use smoothing out.
Glad to make it HOME! Congrats on your successful second LD!!
Hey, congratulations on finishing. This is pretty polished visually. The camera scrolls very smoothly, what function did you use? Is the camera velocity proportional to the distance from the ship?
I have a couple of pieces of (hopefully constructive) feedback.
First, I think the difficulty is pretty dependent on randomness as opposed to skill; asteroids and ships are often so fast that it's all but impossible to dodge them.

Also it would be nice if it were clearer when our ship is taking damage. For a while I flew around holding an asteroid in front of me, thinking that it was protecting me from damage, when in fact it wasn't!
Good job, though, this is an impressive offering. I also think you did a good job of picking an appropriate scope. One of these days I'm going to learn that lesson myself :).

Well done, nice idea too.  Controls and physics in general are way to fast and feeling sort of weird, but that's not necessarily a bad thing.  Instead of just spawning in random warp cores I think it would make more sense if you need to destroy enemy ships to get their warp cores.

Sparky: The camera velocity is indeed proportional to the distance from the ship, I think it does give nice and smooth results. You can of course look at the code, it's in the GameWorld class... About your feedback, I agree with all of it, but in 48h you have to get your priorities right... :-)

description:
This is our first game, we've made for LudumDare. ingame you will find a short explanation how the game works and what to do. We spend about 16 hours of coding and planing to this game. We hope you will enjoy playing it.
It is necessary to have jre6 for playing the game.
author: glethien
title: HelgasWorldDomination
comments: can't locate the source for this game
This is a JAM entry: no source required.  Overall, very interesting game, but since it was a two player game I had no opponent so I didn't stick with it for long.  Great work.
This could be quite a cool game to whip out.
Unfortunately, no matter how I click, I always send out all my units.

description:
Had a lot of fun with the theme, hope you enjoy the game too. No sounds sadly, but a lot of explosions.
Written in Java.
--Game Info--
Lost in outer space, no defenses but your trusty mining hook.
Grab enemy ships using the mouse and launch them back at their friends.
Enemy types:
Red dwarfs: tiny red drone ships, spawned by mother drones. Harmless for you but when used right they can be useful.
Plain drones: red-white, and suicidal. Don't get them too close or they will bash your hull apart.
Shooter drones: With a blue core these spit out plasma bolts like crazy.
Shield drones: A blue shield gives these units some extra bit.
Elite drones: blue-white, and out to get you. Can't outrun these babies.
Mother drones: Slow and bulky, these ships spawn red dwarfs all around. Grab one if you need some good old firepower.
Bomb drones: The pulsating ones make big badaboom.
All drone types (except dwarfs) can be combined.
Make crazy combo's to get lot's of points.
author: ZomBuster
title: Graphell
comments: The concept sounds cool, but I'm getting a ridiculous amount of lag ):
Sorry for that, optimization is not one of my strong points
that's too bad, causes it's otherwise a very enjoyable game :)
- java freezes firefox completely for 10 seconds while loading the game :(  (it does that all the time apparently, not just for your game)
- wasd is not okay with an azerty keymap :-
Nice game! It shares a lot of the gameplay with my entry, just more focused on pure gameplay while mine is more focused on graphics and stuff.
It's hard to tell if the concept was working out or not due to the performance problems.

I thought this was really cool, but it was really hard to see what was going on when everything is a circle. I also wasn't sure if I was taking damage from touching enemies so I didn't really feel like I was in any danger. Some sound effects and a clearer health bar would probably help there.
I think this could be a really cool game if polished up a bit.

description:
Simple game, made in about 5 hours to make up for the terrible mess I made of my RTS compo attempt.
Read Post:
http://www.ludumdare.com/compo/2010/08/23/from-the-clutches-of-satan-himself/
Watch Timelapse:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lLnPGWhUeug
author: TheGrieve
title: From The Clutches Of Satan Himself

description:
Press i in Titlescreen for Instructions.
Direct the Enemies into the viruses.
You cant attack directly.
You can only influence teh enemies to Damage themselfes.
author: Chickenwing
title: Enemyinfection
comments: Neat game, noticing the lack of sound, but a good concept
Took me a while but I hit 11K points.   I couldn't figure out how to destroy the packs of critters sitting near the center.  The help screen was important and well detailed.  Nice job =)
Interesting game, it was hard at first, I kept running out of viruses.
I found a bug though, you do not get new viruses when you restart the game.
Very nice effort! It feels like there's a potential gem buried in this game - it's just too difficult in its current state to find it (especially with the no viruses on restart bug)...

I keep running out of viruses... I can't figure out a reliable way to get rid of the fast little critters, so they keep on killing me. The help screen was nice, but I feel the game is too fast for the amount of stuff to remember...
I think this could be really nice with a gentler difficulty curve and perhaps a tutorial type approach that introduces enemies / viruses one at a time (oh and music / sound).
Thanks a lot for your comments.

description:
The idea is simple.
Your weapons are your enemies!
As you pilot the ship across the space with one hand, you must fight against the monsters inside your ship in minigames with your other hand.
WARNING: A LOT OF IMAGINATION IS NEEDED, AS THE GRAPHICS ARE ONLY ABSTRACT SHAPES, AND KEY PLOT POINTS AND EXPLANATIONS MAY BE MISSING!
author: zlash
title: Enemies, (Such) as Weapons.
comments: Quite challenging! I'm not one that's good at multitasking. The story is also pretty entertaining, despite being so long.
That is a LOT of dialogue!
So punishing! I'm all for difficulty, but it'd be nice if A) I could take one or two hits before I died and B) I could restart the game (post-novel-length-dialogue) without reloading the page.
wow it's really hard, didn't last longer than ~10 seconds :D
good idea, although better graphics wouldn't hurt.
I screwed up basically right away after the extremely lengthy dialogue that I don't think I can stand to go through again :(
You seriously need to edit your dialogue, I felt like I was playing Metal Gear Solid!

Argh, those minigames are punishing. And I hate to say it but the writing in the opening got on my nerves quite a bit. Especially when I tab through all of it only to last 2 seconds in the game itself.
Still, high marks for the idea.
Nice that there is an intro; bad that it goes on (and on). Thankfully I could skip it.

I barely had time to work out what the two concurrent games were before I died. I can't imagine anyone could come to those games completely blind and succeed, even if they only had to play one at once! Remember that with games like this, other players don't have the deep understanding of how they work on first glance, that you, as the game developer, have. Maybe I'm just getting old...

description:
Yeah, this was mostly just for me testing real-time enemies, lol not exactly expecting anything good from it. I had to downgrade the project into something smaller and easier since I had very little time added to the already small amount of time provided, but hey, it was a good experience.
Move with the arrow keys, use space to shoot your enemy absorber ray, if it hits an enemy you get a new power with the gun based on the enemy which you also press space to use
*Soldiers = commando fist
*Bolts = lightning
*Wolf = claw(slightly better than fist)
*Bat = flight(test-room only)
note that the movement is tile-based since I didn't have that much time, good luck
author: Dslayer27
title: EA X3000
comments: I am unsure what keeps killing me in the final room?  I cannot seem to grab the mysterious beast.  Get killed 2/3 of time by first enemy in first level
It's Ok, bu the movement needs work. try and get the movement nice and smooth. Also, the sprites could do with a bit of work.

Hum, just compiled from source (btw, can you remove your source package, and mark your other link as windows + source? Source comes without data, and the binary comes with the source...), it starts and all, but it's obviously too fast! Any idea?
Ok, found why, add install_timer/remove_timer calls in your main!
Ok, the game is interesting, but the lack of smootheness and the speed of the movements make it very hard.
I definitely need more instructions to understand this game. I read the instructions, tried several times the test room, pressed all keys to see what they did... but I just don't get it.
Also it doesn't help that the game doesn't react very well to keypresses and that the keys are "x", "c" and "space"... (Note: I played under Wine.)
Interesting idea, but the laggy gameplay is annoying.

The game seems tile based. And thats not a good idea for such a game design. It feels really laggy. Also its not clear what the goal of the game is. The weapon is somewhat strange... The actual status of my weapon is not shown. And its too fast.

Yeah, the movement was much better in the original version, but I changed it since the game couldn't be finished due to errors because of it, I'll make a more clear game in the next LD, thanks for the comments.

description:
The game is very short but fun.
This is my first LD. Have mercy.
author: benjaminum
title: Dr. Stein's Super Weapons VS Giant Robots
comments: Overall good concept but a way to control in which direction the repelled objects move would be great. Loved the 1337 speak :-D

Really innovative game concept, and well-executed in that the innovative part of the concept works really well.  Technical notes: the general mechanics, i.e. jump and move, are a bit touchy for my taste.  The dialogue and heart containers are a nice touch, although the sounds seem like an afterthought.

Very cool... the controls were a bit touchy, and the camera is not too well centered, which means that most of the time I would fall down hoping I would get to another platform, since I couldn't see what lay below...
I like the basic mechanic a lot. Pretty charming visuals too. :)

It's kind of awkward that the only way to control the repulsion direction is to first set an object down, then get on one side of it. Maybe if you added a force in the direction the player is moving, that would help?

Fantastic concept: I love the magnet controls.  To improve the great game, I would SLOW it down: a lot.  The jumping and movement seems insane and extremely hard to control with finesse.  Overall, fantastic work.  I am very impressed, and my favourite part is the NPC dialog.  Wicked.
I agree with Breakdance that you should probably slow it down quite a bit. Other than that I think it is pretty cool.

I really liked this, it had the most charming graphics out of any that I have seen so far. The gameplay needs some work, it's really hard to fight the robots without dying, but really easy to just run past them. I loved the intro! Really funny stuff.
I liked it a lot! Very innovative and fun to play!
It also seemed to run rather too fast for me - especially jumping, and the speed made it very hard to use the attract/repel mechanic
Still managed to get to the end, though

Nice to have added a bit of dialogue to make the game less flat than most of the other entries. The magnetic effects were nice, and I am sure could be expanded upon to be central to the game-play, but actually throwing robot heads around was a little cumbersome.
Seemed to be lots of spikes directly under drops that you couldn't see until you'd fallen onto them. Seemed a bit unavoidable unless you were psychic.

This was pretty fun to play although it took a bit of working out. I spent a while trying to destroy the robots right at the start before giving up and realising I was meant to just jump past them. I liked the lo-fi visuals and the simple attract/repel mechanic worked well although sometimes it was tricky to maneuver using long runs of the magnetic blocks. Could do with some tweaking to the camera to make it obvious when you are supposed to drop down.
Yeah it was fun, controlled a little fast and wasn't mapping wasn't right for me, at first I assumed that the holes where insta kills like in most plat formers.

description: Decided to make a quick jam entry. Total development time: about one hour. It's just about the simplest thing that anyone could make for this theme. I did however end up bypassing Unity's physics and collision detection systems, which is something I aim to explore further in future projects. My compo entry tries to somewhat work with the Unity physics and collision and it's kinda terrible in that area.
author: pekuja_jam
title: Dodge
comments: Not bad.  Simplistic but functional.  Using Unity for this kind of game is like hammering a nail with a tank, but the game is just as described.  I would have loved some use of Unity's strengths: maybe the baddies could have been 3d robots or asteroids, etc, some sound, maybe some cool explosion particle systems when red buddies collide, maybe they could speed up over time... there's a lot of room for improvement, but it works perfectly and for a game you spent only one hour on, not bad at all.
Well, I used Unity mostly because I'm most comfortable with it, and because I was able to build *something* in the hour that was left of the compo when I started. ;-)

description:
My first time entering the Ludum Dare competition. It was a hard theme for me, but I managed to come up with something. =)
I'm terrible at making background music, so only the title screen has some. Used SFXr and my microphone to make the sound effects though.
You play a little penguin who starts off with a limited number of snowballs (use them wisely!), fending off snow enemies that are invading your little glacier. You can then make snowballs from the remains of defeated enemies to continue fighting and surviving. Harder enemies come out over time and such.
Instructions are in game.
Made with GM.~
author: Meep
title: Defend Your Glacier
comments: Nicely done! I liked the enemy creativity, thought it was pretty funny that the sledding snowman cried every time you hit him :P
anyway its a cute game with cute sounds, it jumps in difficulty pretty quick and the action controls are a tad odd, but once you get over that, its an amusing game
I changed the mediafire link to a Dropbox one~
Nice little game, fun for a while.

Cute, cute, cute. The artwork is really perfect. I loved the take on the theme, which just goes to show how much the backstory is important - explaining that you use the enemy AS the weapon makes the difference.
The game got very hard, very quick, and I didn't last long. Solidly done, though, and I liked the sounds too.

Thanks for the feedback everyone.~ Sorry about the jump in difficulty. I rushed the spawns for people to get a chance to see the variety of enemies I made and didn't have much time to balance things. x_x
Very cute! And I love penguins!
Nice character sprite, movement feels right, several enemy types

Little tip for parallax scrolling - the further back the layer is, the more slowly it should scroll - your background layers seemed to be moving faster than the foreground, which didn't quite look right
Woops, I was only focused on the front mountains moving faster than the back mountains that I didn't realize they were moving faster than the water and everything else =<

description:
Constatine Sucks is a platformer based on sucking souls, and using their abilities. For example, blue souls let you jump higher, and red souls let you explode (without harming yourself, of course). Features 10 levels of increasing difficulty.
Also, the ZIP contains:
-Game executable
-Game source (GM8 pro required)
-Ending music (.wav)
-Ending music (PXTone source file)
author: Cosine
title: Constatine Sucks
comments: Congrats on doing something other then "enemies as ammo." I liked this one. Good variety of powerups.
Took me some time to figure out the controls due to the small text on the bottom.
If anyone else is confused: Z switches slots and X collects souls to use.
Pretty fun! Would like to see more abilities!
I like this quite a bit.
It was ambitious of you to make a platformer in 48 hours! The collision is a bit glitchy and movement is a bit awkward, but it works. That's pretty impressive.
I think the level design is the best part of the game. You really managed to do a lot with a small number of elements.
I'd love to see a more polished version of this. I don't necessarily think that adding more enemies would be a good idea, I like the simplicity of it.

Oh, by the way, it would be nice if picking up a second soul would automatically place it in a free slot if one is available. Right now it overwrites whatever's in the selected slot. A second minor note is that the up key seems to be unresponsive while I am pressing right. This caused me a lot of trouble when using the green powerup, as the second jump often wouldn't fire.
I quite liked this, thanks for making it :).

description:
You are the virus, as an infected you can infect others, which will then carry your virus giving them the ability to unknowingly infecting others.
But be careful, watch out for the antibacterial spray!
Made in GameMaker 8 as I cannot code well at all :)
*I apologise for the size of the download, I also apologise if anyone gets lag from the game, it plays fine on my computers but I didn't have a chance to test it on any other machines.
After looking at my game for a second without stress I've come to realise maybe the types of bacteria should switch colours in a later version in the future, as the healthy bacteria current have red tails
*UPDATE* 23/08/2010
Thanks to everyone for the great comments, after reading your comments it's made me realise how little explanation the game gives and it raises way more questions than I thought it would.
After thinking about it, it would have worked nicely if I had the infected bacteria leave a trail of virus behind it, and then if the ones that have been infected do the same, so the spray then removes that when it's hit. There's a lot more I could do with it, but I'm still fairly happy with what it turned out like, even if the main goal is score based.
author: Attack
title: Bac
comments: The antibacterial spray seems to appear at random and without warning, making it basically impossible to dodge, so the game over always felt rather arbitrary with nothing I could do to affect it. With the limited screen space it was hard to tell if my minions/other infected bits were doing much spreading when I wasn't around to see. Simple concept though, and executed well. Good graphics!

Great graphics, gameplay seemed a tiny bit slow, the spray is ruthless!  No real defense against it.  I'm not really sure I understood why turning the blue things green was doing something other than gaining points, it didn't seem to fight off the spray.
A good concept, but I agree that the player needs some kind of defense against the spray.  It's a little too random as it is.
The first time I played the game the spray hit me within a second of starting it... there really needs to be some defense against it.
I'm not sure how this links with the theme either.
@sinalta You're infected and the healthy bacteria are an enemy, you infect them and then they infect each other, effectively using them as weapons.
When I downloaded the zip, it was corrupt and wouldn't open, I will try again
@Andrew Marsh apologies my website seems to be down, hopefully it will be back up soon, I image my partner is messing around with the server

Great and slightly weird soundscape. I didn't really grasp the challenge involved. Seems like you just move around at random, touching bacteria that don't look like you, and then inevitably get eliminated by an instant spray cloud that you have no chance to avoid? One interesting twist could be that player control is transfered to another infected bacterium if your current avatar gets destroyed. That would seem in line with the anonymous/homogenic nature of germs, and the fact that your infectees have all the same abilities as you (except perhaps intelligence). It would require a change in balance though, to provide any kind of challenge when you have a number of backup bodies to use. Maybe some other form of bacteria would fight back in a similar way, reducing your buddy swarm. On another note, it's annoying to have the start button show you the exact same instructions screen that you just viewed voluntarily a moment ago. Either show no instructions when pressing play, or remember that the player has read them earlier. They should not show up automatically the second time you play, either.

Was a bit confused by the instructions as you say that the healthly germs hurt you when they touch you, regardless a nice simple and easy concept, it's nice when you touch one bacteria near a swarm of them that they all of a sudden turn, is cool to infect things!
About the spray, I didn't mind too much, after all you are a bacteria, life isn't easy!
Nice sound effects, loving the title screens atmospheric squelching
@DrPetter hey thanks for the great comment, that is a great idea of changing the game to be more interesting.
Also with the start button show you the instructions I always do that as people don't always read the instructions so I wanted to force them on the player, apologies for that being annoying to you.

description:
My game is the story of an ant named Joe, who was captured by humans and placed in a anthill full of small arms, deadly for an ant.
This game was made in Game Maker 8 PRO.
The Source is included in the Windows file.
->The Post-mortem version had some bugs fixed and improved gameplay.
author: G@briel
title: Anthill
comments: I just played through the game and I must say: It's way too hard and most of the time you have no idea what you're doing or where you're going. The best part is avoiding bullets and running in circles near the towers.

The controls are quite troublesome as you can turn very fast without going to a full stop (which probably mean that you're going to be hit by a bullet). Also I often hit the walls when walking in corridors.

It seems like you've aimed for too man features (different towers and levels and should maybe have focused more on the core game play. If the controls and movement of the ant had been polished, I wouldn't miss the arrow tower or rocket laucnher (especially the arrow tower.. it killed me way too often).

Definately a challenging game.  Level 2 took some work to get through, and so far I've not made it through Level 3.  I want to come back and play this game further - the auto save game feature is nice =)
My ant got stuck on walls where it felt like he should have just glided through.  Other than that the controls seemed fine.
My ant died some pretty horrible deaths, all due to my mistakes of course =)   The triple shot weapon is especially deadly.

First off, I think the artwork and sound are great, and the idea is fairly simple and neat. Couldn't get past level two though, as it was quite hard. The leaves should probably refill your health entirely, otherwise you lose way more health trying to get them than you gain back! I also didn't like getting stuck to the walls, as that was my most common cause of death.

I'm not really sure where the theme fits in. I tried getting two towers to fire at each other and blow each other up, but it was too hard to avoid getting shot myself. Other than that I don't know where the theme could be!
But well done on a nice attempt at a 48-hour game, and it does work. You could be proud of what you achieved in the time, and good luck with the next compo :)
I have a few small suggestions that I think would improve your game a lot.

description:
Use the arrow keys.
Goal #1: Stay alive. Use left, right, and up arrows (or Z) to move and jump around.
Goal #2: Wreck enemies. Use down arrow (or X) to duck into safety and slide around. Pop up beneath enemies.
Goal #3: Figure out how to force the invader back from whence it came (space).
~ made in Flash, using Flashpunk. The web link will work for more than just computers running Windows.
Things I did not create during the 48 hours:
Flashpunk (a great library for making flash games -- see flashpunk.net)
standingwave2 (an as3 library for manipulating audio stuff)
Mover.as (a class I created long ago; I use it in pretty much everything I make; I hear that's allowed)
author: droqen
title: Undermine
comments: I really like it! its hard to get used to, but once you got it its really fun :D
Is it? I'll reupload source somewhere else then :x
Neat idea, ditto manuel777, Controls are a bit hard to get used to.
this idea is incredible and so fun! Really good work!

Really weird controls, they take some getting used to. Instructions screen isn't massively clear which doesn't help, and unfortunately the gameplay is frustrating even when you know what you're doing.
I really like the idea though, I think it's awesome even though I'm rubbish at it. Enemy variety is good.
Sound is nice, and for some reason reminds me of the music I made for my first LD game so points for unintentional nostaligia (although yours is better).
Bug: running off the side of the platform doesn't kill you.
Very hard to get the hang of, and the bug with falling off the platform (and not dying, etc) became annoying after a bit... it's a good idea, needs better level design to ease the learning curve...
I cannot at all reproduce this "falling off the screen doesn't kill you" bug! Are you sure you aren't just being slightly impatient? You need to wait a couple of seconds after the music drops off.
I love the idea for this game, also this little informatic at the start is great. Good job
The soldiers annoyed me until I realized that they could be used to shoot at the invader. I also wasn't quite sure what to do with the little square guys, but that didn't take long.
I liked the subtle hint at the instruction screen that the goal was to push the invader off the top. It may have been slightly too subtle, though.

One niggle is that the gameplay seems to encourage you to pick either the top or bottom level and stick with it for extended periods of time. If you neglect a level, it's very hard to retake it from the inevitable hordes of enemies. Early game, the bottom level is preferable because the hard-to-deal-with soldiers tend to stick to the top level. Late game, the bottom seems to get swarmed, and it's easier to stay on the top level and use the soldiers to shoot at the invader.
Hoo wow, very nice indeed! I'm not sure what it is exactly about it that I find so appealing. I think it's the entire package.

All the enemies behave differently and are easily readable, the boss monster is iconic to the extreme, and the music getting more and more muted as you get hurt is a very nice effect. I just miss sound effects!
Fun game! I like the way the filter on the music conveys your health, kind of like the shell shock effect in games like Call of duty.
Really fun game! The enemies with the buttons on their heads and the ones with the guns were the most frustrating, but I managed to beat it. =P
Sometimes I would push the enemies really high, and sometimes they wouldn't go high at all. I couldn't figure out what it was that made the difference.
The gunner enemies only fly so high when killed, and the boxy orange guys (the ones who look like you) need to be in a certain state to be killed.
To everyone else, thank you :D I am happy for this great reception. Half of me wants to respond to every person ever, and the other half tells me not to.

description:
"Your father built the greatest empire this world has ever seen, but he never saw its true potential.  Now it's your turn.
We await your command, and the world awaits your lash."
Risk style game, where your opponents are ridiculously powerful but you can use diplomacy to coerce your opponents into fight each other.
Revision 175 is the final one as of the end of the Jam (half playable, but throughly unfinished).
Need SFML, G++, Lua5.1 to compile; and bazaar to get the source.  On Linux, ./waf configure build will configure and build the game. ./waf run will run it.
A more complete version of the game, plus Windows, Linux, and OSX binaries are upcoming.
author: SirNuke
title: The Strings That Bind the World

description:
The story (which is an important part of the game) is here:
http://www.ludumdare.com/compo/2010/08/22/singularity-smash/
and the screenshot is not very good but it's hard to take a screenshot of a game that uses both hands.
author: quin
title: Singularity Smash
comments: Nice idea for a game mechanic. The graphics are a little simple, of course, but they get the job done. The screen gets crowded before too long, and they end up running into each other by themselves. This game could use some polish, but I like what I see so far!

As much as the graphics are simplistic, it's definitely better than having ugly graphics. The gameplay was nice, and all in all I liked it. My only complaints are that it felt strange having the ship always face one way, and that the cursor can go way beyond the screen, which makes it hard to find sometimes.
Entar: Why are you so much better at the games I make than I am?
Pretty good. After reading the intro I was very pumped up. As you said, the graphics aren't much, but you got the job done.

I laughed at the idea of people having such crazy conversations with their computer one day, (just like when star trek does it), as if it's better to query a computer so verbosely, but that's a programmer's nitpick, and doesn't detract from your game or story. ;)
Crashes on execute, aw.  Looks interesting though.
@deveinmoore- I had the same issue. You need the XNA framework to run it (it's the second link he posted).
It's pretty neat, for how simple it is.  The graphics are nice and clean, and it fits the theme well.
I think it'd be interesting if holding down the left mouse would maintain a singularity that rapidly drained energy, to get larger groups.

Graphics are competent and not bad at all. I like the sparse style, actually. I would have liked to see more representation of the "singularity", besides a circle (I understand it affects the world a little longer than the circle is there?). Also, why aren't the enemy gun pellets attracted to the singularity as well?

description:
You have no weapons and are attacked (for no reason?) by evil robots. Avoid the robots and trick them to crash into each other! (you can even do combos!)
If you get too many robot hugs you die!
Sound generated using SFXR and http://tones.wolfram.com/generate/ and edited using Audacity.
Programmed in Unity using C#
Graphics done in Photoshop.
author: timgarbos
title: Robots <3 Monster
comments: I really liked the simplicity of it. You carried the theme across very succinctly and it was fun to play. I laughed the first time I died because it looked like my corpse was about to be gangraped, but that's neither here nor there. :P
Haha! I thought about that too :P It wasn't on purpose, but I guess it fits the name.

There's a minor issue with say... the score not resetting when you die and restart and the difficulty could do with ramping up more later on - otherwise you have a really fun game and the sounds and graphics work great!
Argh! Damnit about the score. I did fix it, just introduced the bug again :P
It only happens sometimes though. It's a matter of which object that is spawned first :P
Fun base gameplay. And many could learn from your choice of scope!
A nice idea. I like the visual and audio department but gameplay wise there is not much happening. Adding some more different robots would make this much better.
This is pretty well made. You were smart to choose a game with relatively few moving parts. It really benefitted the level of polish of the final product. Good job.
I fixed some bugs and did some balancing and added it as a Jam version. I also included some art work that never made it to the first release :)  - The name actually makes sense now!
Fantastic! The best LD game I've rated so far! Simple, effective and polished!

The music is lovely, the effects are gorgeous, the characters are charming, a neat interpretation of the them (I love the way you've got two types of robots, which spices up the "make enemies collide" mechanic a lot). Wonderful to look at, easy to play, and I know I'm going to be coming back to this one.
I can't even think of a problem with it! Top notch, sir, I bow down to you! ;)
Very detailed and polished graphics! (The walking robot sprite was very cute) Nice music and fluid controls.
Could have used more variety in the gameplay which gets old after a while.
Smooth control, good graphics and very fun to play.
It has a fun whimsical feel.
Good fun and very polished - very well done!! Really liked the music too!
Could maybe have used another type of robot or two, but still great. Oh, btw - the game doesn't run in Google Chrome (Unity issue I guess, but made forced me to switch to IE to play - blech).

description:
Help the green alien to defeat the robots, recycle your dead enemies to new bullets or to energy !
good luck weak human !!
Instructions:
- move left/right,
- space jump,
- change shoot direction up/down
- 1,2,3,4 shoot
- E recycle energy
- B recycle bullets
author: athanazio
title: Recycling Robots
comments: It looked good, played good and was fun. My one complaint is that you couldn't aim downwards, which made it hard going down steps.
Very frenetic, but once I figured out what was going on and what the surprise was, I was able to play it just fine.  Good job!
Dammit.  I submitted a comment and committed my (null) vote.  Can I get my comment/vote removed so I can vote for real?
Aiming is quirky. It's difficult to find correct weapons with right angle and enough velocity for way too many situations. Graphics are quite ok.
The music is awful with the few second loops. Sound effects when hitting and being hit would've been great.

I didn't really understand why there were so many types of bullets. Is it for use against different colors of enemies? The game physics seemed really fast, but the framerate was kinda low, so everything looked kinda choppy and it was hard to always determine what was going on.
