author: XMunkki
title: Psi Keepers
comments: This is great fun! A healthy dose of strategy, too... Nice work.

Fun stuff! I'd say this captures the essence of the theme extremely well. At first I was hoping for more variation, but once I realized the strategy involved it got a lot more interesting... good job!

I'm not sure if I managed to figure out the aforementioned strategy, but it was a nicely implemented game. I do wish explosions took out all nearby bombers instead of just the target. When my score got up around the 150 mark, I simply couldn't click fast enough to take out all the bombers.
However, the game sits well with the theme, and the graphics were nice. Well done!

I thoroughly enjoyed this game.  It wasn't particularly expansive on gameplay, it has a strong concept that fits the theme well.  I just wish the explosions had some area of effect, since you can only kill one at a time!
Muutaman erilaisen mÃ¶rÃ¶n vielÃ¤ tehny ni ois ollu aikas kova peli. Muuten kyllÃ¤ teeman mukainen ja toimiva idea, pelikin pyÃ¶ri ongelmitta eikÃ¤ bugaillu mitÃ¤Ã¤n. Good job!
I wasn't sure from the name and description of it, but after playing it I love it, it's really addictive and fits the theme really well :)
Only thing I will pick on is the sfx were slightly annoying, but still bearable.

I wasn't sure about this game based on the screen shot, but after playing it, I like it. I would like to see you add waves in the game so the player can rest in between and have new enemy types show up later as the game progresses (which I'm sure you probably would've done if not for the time limit)

Good simple fun, definitely one of the more enjoyable entries I've played so far. The concept is simple and effective, the graphics look nice when they're all moving, and having a huge swarm of enemies following me was great fun. You should add some Benny Hill music in your next version :P

I'm not sure I got the strategy element of it though, and I felt it could do with more variation too. Maybe some more enemy types, or some power-ups, or some way to chain combos together. But what you already have is already good solid and polished fun. Nice stuff!!

It's entertaining and well made, good job. It would have been nice if there was a blast radius though because even though I knew there wasn't I kept instinctively sending the bombers to very crowded areas which was totally the wrong strategy... Far better to pick off the stragglers. Would have easily won counter-intuitive! :)
This is pretty visually polished. I particularly like the lighting effect.
Oh, and I like the way there's a special effect when we get a game over, that's a nice touch.

I wonder if I missed something on the strategy front- I messed around a bit, but I never could get any multiple kills or chain reactions or anything. It seems that each controlled bomber can only take out exactly one target. Am I missing something?

description:
Well, this was a total failure.
Let me tally the ways.
Friday, August 20th, 2010
Had to work late, and an electrical storm kicked out my internet. I had no way to see what the friggin' theme was, but I was tired anyway and had to be at work the next morning for another 12 hour shift.
Saturday, August 21st, 2010
Got home super late, still no internet. Luckily I checked the theme while at work, so I had an idea of what I wanted to do. But being this far behind was depressing... and knowing that I couldn't update my LD progress and participate with the rest of the community... or possibly even SUBMIT the game... I didn't have much enthusiasm. Plus I was super tired yet again and only worked on my idea for about an hour.
Sunday, August 22nd, 2010
THE FINAL DAY. STILL NO INTERNET.
So I toiled away for about 4 hours and ended up with a little tech demo and nothing else.
It's not a game, and I didn't even have time to implement enemies. Only the weapons that were ONCE enemies. This is like seeing the sequel before the prequel. It doesn't translate well.
I still had a chance at the jam, though... so I decided to slap some SFX and music into the game very quickly... with an intent to cram some more programming in on Monday night.
Monday, August 23rd, 2010
HAD TO WORK LATE AGAIN. The internet was finally fixed when I got home, so I spent another hour or so catching up on the LD site and prepping my tech demo for an upload. Didn't have time to add anything new, so I didn't even bother.
And there you have it... my LD 18 time line. OH JOYOUS JOY. I missed it all, and that sucks. I love seeing game previews on Friday and Saturday, then playing the end result on Sunday. It's the best part of Ludum Dare, if you ask me.
MAN SUCKS AND BLOWS
-------------------
Use your enemies as weapons! AWESOME!
Suck up the tiny babies (feature not implemented!) and shoot them (feature IS implemented!) at high velocity towards the face of their evil mother! (feature not implemented!)
Rack up tons of combo points (feature not implemented!) and upgrade your VACUU-GUN (feature not implemented!) to take on the bigger and badder baddies! (feature not implemented!)
Yeah, you get the idea.
You basically run around and shoot little yellow babies in all kinds of directions. That's it.
---------------------------
LEFT AND RIGHT ARROW KEYS - move, man!
UP AND DOWN ARROW KEYS - change the angle, man!
SPACE BAR - shoot out babies, man!
---------------------------
author: SonnyBone
title: Man Sucks And Blows

description:
Here is my very short (and broken/buggy) game!
Arrow Keys to move.
Hold spacebar to mind control.
Keep holding spacebar to blow up mind controlled enemy.
Press E to flick switches.
Press R to reset the current screen.
UPDATE:
I've taken the downloads down since the game was more broken and buggy than I initially thought! Better luck next compo I guess.
author: Gobo
title: LunarMind
comments: Uploading the other binaries for Linux + Mac shortly.
I can't get past the second room. I flip the switch and the wall comes down, but I can walk past it or jump over it...
A very short, but interesting quiet experience.
As for the theme you can take over the mind of a spider and use it for pulling levers or kill it, but you can't really use it as a weapon.

I like the idea and concept, but the levels are really basic and doesn't use it to the full extend. It would be awesome to create some sort of puzzle games where you had to take over the spiders and pull the right levers in order to get pass some obstacle. You have some great elements.
Mind Control + boom, reminds me of an old game.
Too bad the spiders can't attack, though...
Fixed the gravity problem, and re-uploaded.

The idea was interesting, but there just wasn't all that much going on, unfortunately. I also found the controls a bit weird - mind controlling felt kind of awkward and I found myself having to keep jumping to get over things instead of just getting over it smoothly. Hopefully you can turn this into something a little more complete eventually!
I've just noticed that it wasn't just the gravity that wasn't relative to time. Most of the animations are broken. Oh well. :P

I didn't the way the rooms reset when I left them. I walked off one screen with three spiders on it to a dead end, then when I went back, I got killed at the edge of the screen before I could do anything. I think the game would have benefited from continuous scrolling, since the "levels" were so tiny in real terms.
Still, nice art style and some interesting ideas.
I liked the idea and it would be cool to see an extended version of it.

description:
Be sure to read the instructions below. There are no instructions in game.
This game is mostly a tech demo since it was too complicated to finish on time. This game requires Pixel shader model 2. You create skeletons using the bones of your enemies and use them to help you fight more enemies. The game was originally going to have the player collect pieces to become a lich but that is not implemented. The bones were also supposed to influence the skeleton's stats but that's also unimplemented.
Be sure to follow the brown dirt paths since I didn't have time to code proper barriers and the enemies are only on the paths. There is currently no way to "win".
Instructions:
The P key (P)ortals you between your sanctum and the outside
The I key Brings up your (I)nventory
Click the sarcophagus to bring up the skeleton maker. Click each bone and place it in the correctly labelled slot in the sarcophagus. There are tooltips to tell you what they are. Click "Create" to make your skeleton.
To destroy a skeleton select him then click the sarcophagus.
Click enemies to attack and click dead enemies to loot them. Click each item then click an inventory slot to move it there.
Right click items in your inventory to destroy them.
ESC quits.
All assets and game code were created from scratch by me. The only reason this game is Jam is because I ran out of time for the compo.
I used C++ with Ogre, CEGUI, OIS, and my Framework with helper classes.
Content was created using Blender, Photoshop, and PixPlant for the terrain textures. Images for the terrain textures were taken during a walk on Saturday.
author: Serilyn
title: Lich
comments: This was really tedious. I like the idea, and yet, clicking on each body part and then on the slot you want it to go to was just boring. I spent a long while walking around without finding anything, too. Sorry man :(
Fantastic graphics.  I really like the shadows, textures, and models.
Interesting concept, but the interface could probably be improved.

description:
Here it is my friends!
This game is called Leave Me Alone; it's about those sad times when life feels overwhelming.
Goal: Entice the things to destroy each other.
Controls:
Arrows = Move.
Space = Restart Level.
X = Start or Continue Game.
-/+/0 = volume/mute.
Please share your thoughts! This is a lonely game, and your thoughts will help me feel less lonely about it.
Coded in AS3 with Flixel. Software used: FlashDevelop, sfxr, Mixcraft, Audacity, Photoshop, Flan.
author: hamburger
title: Leave Me Alone
comments: Fun concept.  Some non-obvious thinking required in some levels, which is nice.
Really nice concept, but the music is annoying after a while
Second AClockWorkLemon, really enjoyed this (especially when I finally beat the map where you're surrounded at the very start, but the music wasn't really my cup of tea.
I liked this one a lot! Very well executed
Awww I'm sad you guys don't like the music. I was really happy with it. Not yer typical game music, but it was exactly the tone I wanted. :)
If I had a little more time I would have put in some text-based cutscene-interludes, which maybe would have supported the intended tone of the music: lonely and overwhelmed.
Anyway I'm glad everyone's enjoying the gameplay.
Very fun game! I liked the level shown in the screenshot where you had to guide the bullets around =P

I liked the idea;  The levels with the streaming bullets were most creative to me.  A brief "get ready" sort of thing would be nice;  Too many times I instantly died because of not having milli-second reaction times at the start of a level.

This is pretty good, I like it. Only problems are a slight input lag, the borders sometimes blink which is annoying, and the life time of the projectiles seem to be variable which means I couldn't finish one level because there was no way to reach the squares. I think.
I rather like this entry. It's an original, fun concept that I thoroughly enjoyed playing.

This one was fun! It would be better if the difficulty didn't go from easy to very hard so quickly, or perhaps there could be a difficulty rating on each level, I nearly gave up on the level before the one in the screenshot. I liked the music, although it was a bit bland and MIDIish.

I didn't manage to finish it (got stuck on the ring-of-tendrils style level).  Seemed a solid exploration of a simple but well realized mechanic (always a good thing).  The music was great and fit, strangely, it felt like it oughtn't.
I don't understand what the title and theme text have to do with anything.

description:
Here you are this simple game.
It's a flash game that you can play on your browser:
Space Jellyfish are invading!
Just catch them and throw them!
author: Zoltam
title: Jellyfish Invaders
comments: There's not much else, but the game is solid in it's simplicity. Use of two turrets in different places, aiming not controllable is a great idea. Also thought that it will be boring quite a while but the difficulty did ramp up with game time.
Would be a good game on a device which lacks good keys, for example a handheld.
Very simple but good. I agree with Pokute, the game would be great on a phone
Good simple game :) - I agree that it would probably be great on a phone! Well done!
It's like UFO Catcher meets Missile Command! It's pretty neat, but gets boring after a while. It also seems like there's a bug that makes the cannon shoot two jellyfish at once, wasting one.
@pekuja: That bug about two jelyfish shot, is fixed out of the competition, in the second version (just click the link and you find the link for version 0.2). Besides, I added some new powerups.

570 points. Is it supposed to fire two at once when you have multiple on board? At first I was catching one, firing one, but then I realized I could capture a lot of them before shooting. Maybe there should have been a bonus system for collecting a lot of enemies, as that seems a little bit harder than to catch/fire/catch/fire. Or maybe you could fire several in a burst as some kind of powerup when you have enough stored. Collision boxes seemed a bit too small, as I often shot an enemy through the edge of another. Cute and relaxing though. The capture thud is a great sound in this context.

description:
So, after tireless effort, I'm finally done.
SOME NOTES:
-The game uses surfaces to draw the view, if your video card doesn't support whatever it is that GM uses for surface drawing (I think it might be pixel shaders? I dunno) you probably won't be able to play the game. I mean, it might WORK, but the screen will be tiny.
-All the controls are either explained in the game, or in the text file. The txt file only includes keys that aren't explained in the game, such as skipping the intro and moving/jumping.
Anyway, thanks for playing! I can't wait to check out what the rest of you guys made.
author: MoltenMustafa
title: Isolation
comments: Hey, great job & I'm glad you kept on going. This plays very smoothly and has a great look. Well done!
I'm sad that I can't play it! Once I get to the title screen, I push enter and it displays the screen showed in your screenshot, which immediately fades to a full black screen.
I really enjoyed this. Simple yet appealing game. I found the snake whip really amusing. =P
@Zillix: Did any error messages pop up? That doesn't sound exactly like a surface issue ... I'll start looking at it. Did you skip the intro or watch it all the way through?

There weren't any visible error messages.  The way I described, I had skipped the intro. If I watch the intro, it quickly shows what I think is the title screen without the words yet, and then fades to black.
Some problem as Zillix. Doesn't help not to skip the intro.

That is really weird. I'm trying to replicate it, but I can't. I don't know if it's a surface drawing error or not, but it could be ...  the thing is, if it were, the game itself shouldn't work at all because the viewports themselves are scaled via surfaces. Hm, strange.
Wow. I've never played a 48 hour metroidvania before, but that was good.

The only frustration I ran into was with the running jump mechanic; sometimes I'd make a jump and sometimes I wouldn't. I was stuck for a while until I realized that (a) running jumps made you go higher and (b) I could also hold down the jump button longer to drift a little higher still.

Yeah run-jumping definitely needed some work, I think it was a combination of the run-speed and the jump height that made it so tedious. If I ever update this game I'll probably make the player jump a tiny bit higher so the harder jumps aren't as annoying. The thing about making the run speed slower is that the player is only 4 pixels wide, so when he's running he is moving 2 pixels every step event. Making him move 1.5 pixels every step would look kinda weird. Thanks for the feedback, by the way, I appreciate it :D
I got it to work on an older computer. I really like these types of games, and it was just the perfect length.  Well done.

Wow, this was awesome! Huge game world with lots to do. Lots of variety to the graphics (even if they weren't very detailed). The jumping was a bit annoying at times, but otherwise the controls were good.

Would have been even better with some music and better sound effects and also a cutscene or something explaining the goal of the game, but I guess you would have a hard time fitting all that into 48 hours.
Really interesting little game, that looked like it had a lot of content (if only I was better at jumping :)). Intro and general style helped greatly.
Not sure that a snake-whip really counted as good use of "enemies as weapons" though.

Very nice!  Had a lot to it for only a 48hr game!  Main things that grabbed me as needing improvement were the jumping being perhaps overly difficult and the final boss didn't flash or anything when I hit him, so I was afraid that I had missed some important upgrade.

description:
You are a roboticist trapped in a secret government with a bunch of malfunctioning robots. Thankfully, even though you are unarmed, you've got skillz in that you can hack most of the robots (except for the orange ones) given the SX3000 replacement circuit board. Hacking requires you sneak up behind a robot when he is not looking and touch him (make sure you have a circuit board and are standing on the ground - not in the air).  The goal: get out of the facility with your life intact.
NOTES *) The preloader does not appear to be working so you
might have to wait a few seconds while staring at
what looks like an almost empty webpage.
0) In normal mode, Z = jump
1) Orange robots are NOT hackable!
2) You must NOT be in the air when you attempt to hack a robot or you WILL fail.
3) Hacks don't last forever, so get done with the bot quickly.
4) It is required that you hack certain bots to open certain security gates. TrackBot opens the Blue gates. WheelBot opens the Red gates.
5) In hacked mode: Z = jump  X = fire
6) Something I failed to get into the game instructions - the exit to each level looks kind of like an elevator door.
7) Stuck on a level with no way to finish it? No problem, just press 'Q' and the level will be reset ... but you will lose a life in the process.
author: recursor
title: HAckBotz
comments: Nice qwirky game. However i didnt do that much hacking past what i needed to do.. However it did entertain me while i played it.
man, hacking a bot this way is actually quite fun
although you lose a star in the fun department due to the fact that you can't restart from the same level once you run out of lives (and you don't have many)... perhaps some continues would help
this is a very good application of the theme
graphics are pretty good, not sure how many stars i should give them
audio is pretty good, i like the voices though it's a LITTLE irritating, could do with some more ambience
humour is there and it works, yay, first game i've rated which has this

overall, i would recommend you learn a real platform with respect to this type of game, i find the concept behind flixel an abomination as it's really not flash... but this is a brilliant game if you ignore its one or two flaws
the community feedback is essentially non-existant following your journal. considering that you got this done with 30 minutes to spare, i find this understandable.
This feels pretty well put together given the time constraint.

I think the main piece of feedback I'd give is that I found the hacking to be a bit twitchy- sometimes it worked when I thought it hadn't, and other times it didn't work when I thought it should have.
Pretty fun! I like what you tried to do with the voice.
My only complaint is how touchy hacking was, I ended up getting shot for being too close a lot, but I guess hacking really is an acquired skill. Ho ho ho.
My only complaint would be that the bots sometimes shoot multiple times in a row making it really hard to dodge.
Extremely cool idea, but far too complex for me to really get into. I feel that spending more time on actual gameplay instead of other elements would have helped greatly.
Graphics are very nice, humor is good (reminds me of "Give Up, Robot").

description:
Instructions:
1. Unzip somewhere
2. Install OpenAL with the provided installer
3. Run bin/LD18.exe
4. Enjoy
Gameplay Info:
The goal is simple: survive and get as high a score as possible. Your ship has no direct offensive weapons, but you can pull a nearby enemy ship in with your tractor beam (Z key in the default settings) to use them as a shield, use their weapons (holding Z fires continuously), or use them as a projectile (press X to throw the ship forward with enough force to destroy another enemy).
You also have the ability to do a "force push" of sorts, by pressing X when you don't have an enemy tractor beam-ed in, any enemies near you will be pushed outward (and possibly into other enemies).
There are occasional powerups that cause slowmo or invincibility for 15 seconds.
The difficulty setting is  a decimal scale from 1 to 4, 1 being pretty tame, and 4 being ridiculous (the difficulty scales up the speed and amount of enemies, bullets etc).
Control options allow for Arrows + X/Z, WASD + Shift/Ctrl and a couple (hopefully) dvorak friendly options.
GPL'd source is included in src.zip within the Windows package.
I'll try to port to Linux, eventually.
author: Riley Adams
title: Fratricide
comments: This is fun, i like the concept of taking ships hostage :)

This is really cool. There were more attack options than I initially assumed, it was hard to stop playing. My favourite attack was definitely shooting enemies back at each other, but using them as a weapon was a novel thought.
My only gripe was the Slow-Motion bonus, which was more annoying than anything else. I just wanted it to go away so I could keep grappling ships.
This game seems to never end!
Since I liked G-Darius, I give this a thumbs-up.  Very nice, hope you flesh it out.
I do agree that the slo-mo powerup just seemed pointless.
This is pretty visually slick for a Ludum Dare game! It's pretty fun too.

description:
Arrows keys to move
Z to push away enemies
X to pick up/ throw a small enemy
The gameover screen is wrong u have to press Z not spacebar, dont have time to reupload etc.
You have to protect the centre crystal of the magic forest from attack. If you die or the crystal its over.
kill red by throwing into the bigger enemies or have the bigger blade enemy cut it down, to kill the blades throw a red enemy at a bomb with it standing near by.
timelapse to come some.
yay my first ludum dare, just made it in time
author: milsom
title: EnemiesOfTheLetterB
comments: The graphics are good, a few technical notes: throwing enemies didn't seem to work often, and I really wished I could move diagonally.  I had a hard time escaping the feeling that I was playing a compiled game engine demo, but I do like the player and enemy designs, the eggplant with eye people are strong characters.

I found it to play really nicely (although I agree about diagonal throwing, and general aiming being tricky).  The graphics are nice, and everything has a good layer of particle polish.  Most of all I felt it moved really smoothly and responsively, which is not always easy to achieve!
The music is very odd, and gives the whole thing a strange vibe...

Love the graphics, and well done with the music - very creepy and foreboding, somehow makes the cute game seem very sombre. The controls on this seem to be super sensitive. I'm going to try it again when I have access to an analogue stick.

thanks for the comments, i agree about the music was a sleep deprivived last minute creation, at the time it felt "mysterious forest" haha. as for the speed and a couple of other bugs i didnt get that at home, on work PC it does that on the webplayer, dont know why it does it, .exe works ok tho
Love the graphics and overall feel! The music and sounds add greatly to the atmosphere. Sorry that the gameplay is so rough.
Great graphics, nice sound, good ideas.  The movement could use a little more polish.  Keep up the wonderful work!  =)
This game would be really cool if it had a bit more of a control system and balance, as it is I really like the sound and the graphics are pretty nice.
First of, the graphics are AWESOME.

The game was alright. I didn't think that picking up and throwing enemies was a massively outside-the-box concept, but mixing it with a defend-the-tower mechanic was fresh and worked well. I loved the explosions!

Very simple to control, although it took me a while to get that you could only throw the little guys if you were facing a big enemy. To be honest, I think it would make more sense if you could always throw them.
The audio was creepy, but also a little annoying. I also didn't work out how to defeat the big purple guys. They seemed immune to the little guys being thrown at them.
Wonderfully polished, and some of the best graphics I've seen in the competition!

description:
This started out as a Glorious Trainwrecks entry, so it has that two-hour-game quality, but it ended taking me 26 hours. Wheeeee~
It's a primitive storytelling experiment!
author: Super
title: Emagtra
comments: I'm glad you didn't include instructions. Took me a minute to work out what was going on. Liked the attractor mechanic but would have liked Y and B to be dangerous to the player. Nice effort, one of the more original games :D

Interesting game, though a bit too easy I think. It was fun trying to figure out just what was happening, and then being pleasantly surprised when the two previous tools combined in an unexpected way on the third level. Heh.
Your host is acting like a jerk and won't let me download.
This application currently has too many requests in its backlog."
Please upload it somewhere else, I want to try it out :)
I like the idea behind this :)
I wish there would have been more levels, i liked the idea. :/
Level 3 finished itself while i was busy responding to an IM. :P
Nice idea. Could do with more challenging levels though.

description:
Its an over-the-head RTS where you control one group of units. Upon killing opponents, you receive materials you can use to upgrade your soldiers at cities.
I have two ways you can play. Either run the Eneapon.exe, or if it doesn't work, drag the LD18.love file on to the Love.exe
author: Tyler
title: Eneapon
comments: Eneapon.exe didn't work on my Vista64+ati at all. Computer went unresponsive for a while. Dragging L18.love on top of Love.exe worked.

Theme implementation is one of the common ones - kill enemies yourself, get powerup. Could've been a lot better if I would've gotten the city thing working (if it was implemented). Only saw the player circles growing.

The game itself doesn't seem to have other content that lots of monsters and loot, few different terrain types and huge map. The only city I found was the one in the beginning square and couldn't figure out what to do there. More documentation on real state of game would be nice - wandering through dozens of screen looking for uncertain content gets boring.
Also, didn't see the source anywhere.
What can you do in the City?
I tried one thing in the city and it crahed.

Weird menu items that don't do anything, "combat" by running towards enemies but never actually coming in contact with them. There was only one city I could find, and I couldn't figure out what to do once I was in there. Basically I wandered down, killing whatever came into view and holding Z when my circles turned red. Not sure what the point of the game was. I saw my circles get slightly larger but I never found any loot or anything to do except move my circles close to other circles.

description:
This is what I managed to come up with during the extended weekend. I've had this idea for a while, and now that I have the base engine going, I'm going to work more on it.
The game has only one level and can't be 'beaten', as there's no congratulary message, but the puzzle itself can be solved, i.e. you can bring the orb to th pedestal. The puzzle's probably too hard for a starter, but I hope you have fun!
author: Hempuli
title: Doors and some other stuff
comments: Yay, I did it! This is pretty satisfying, good job and thanks for making it.
Pretty cool!  Good puzzle.  This could be turned into a polished game that could sell: a whole bunch of fun doors-you-can-move puzzles would be great.
Oh man, this is so hard! Really cool though, and really satisfying to complete.
Still can't beat it, but it's an awesome concept with amazing graphics. Top stuff!!
Got it. This is a brilliant puzzle.
Very nice graphics and good programming (from what I can see). I haven't solved the puzzle yet, but I'll try again :).
I can get anything up to the next level except myself. Any hints?

Are you supposed to be able to bring doors through doors? If you position yourself so that you're touching the door, but the door you're holding isn't touching it much, then you can walk bring a door through.
I walked through door 1 carrying another door 1 and it caused me not to exist!
Oh, I thought I prevented one from doing that. Haha, thanks for noting, gotta fix it. Of course, bringing doors through doors might present some rather cool puzzles, but also a lot of hassle.
Alan Lynn: I'm not sure which way you got to the top, but can't you throw a door up there before getting there yourself? There's the springboard and all!
I can get a door up top fine. Then walking through the matching door would get me up there. The problem is, once I put a door up top, I don't know how to get to the matching door.

description: A druid who walks around banging evil spirits into each other.
author: Scramasax
title: Camma The Huntress
comments: The game isn't much in its current state, but if you added some interesting enemies, and put in some real levels (like in a forest or in a dungeon), then you might be onto something.
I found a couple bugs. When you run around there's some serious terrain popping. At the end of the attack animation there's a weird frame. If you hold down ctrl, the character stays on that frame.
I like the main character and the explorational feel. Gameplay needs much more work.
It doesn't feel finished. No real game or goal in there yet, but the graphics and models aren't bad.
It just crashes for me immediately.
I like the auto targeting and how the enemies fly around like hockey pucks when you hit them.
Couln't get it working, crashed during the console loading box
It crashed for me when I ran the exe, but running the bat file worked!

It's really good to see a 3d entry.  You should highlight the character that you spent so much the time on!  First move the camera in closer for now at least.  I edited cameratune.cfg and moved it to (0, 140, -320), give that a go.  Also the player and enemies aren't getting lit, you should try to throw some lights on them to give them more depth.  Ideally match it up close to the terrain lights.
I like the main character. The game has potential.

I also like the main character, although her animation is a bit stiff. The gameplay is pretty simplistic, and the 3D visuals don't really feel like a good fit for it. You could keep working on it though, add some more interesting combat, etc.

description:
Build a giant amoeboid castle out of the remains of your defeated opponents.
<arrows> or <w, a, s, d> to move
<mouse> to fire
Enemy castles are green. Destroy the core of a castle to render it neutral. Once you have defeated an enemy castle, you can harvest any remaining components by walking over them.
Take your spoils back to your castle, and build by clicking and dragging.
author: Sparky
title: Bubble Tag
comments: Very nice, I love expansion games! Took a few seconds to get my head around the concept, but it falls together well. Good job!
nice, great graphics and intuitive gameplay :D
Fun stuff, I love the visual style!
I love rts/expansion type games, so this was great to play. It looks lovely, too. Nicely implemented.
Wow, that was pretty cool. Had a lot of fun, things get pretty hard later on.

Wonderful graphics, smooth and silky and attractive.  Great concept, I really like the blobbiness of your castles.  Took me a few moments to figure out.  Fantastic job: with more modes, colours, and weapons this could really be a fantastic strategy/shooter game.  I'm very impressed.
It's not immediately apparent that it's going to be a hopeless struggle to just last as long as you can, so there's quite a disparity between the initial experience and the endgame.
I'm not sure how I'm meant to avoid being swarmed by a whole bunch of enemies at once, but when that happens I don't seem to have any ability to stop them.
well done, I liked the expanding / enemy-harvesting part.
but sadly I got somehow stuck outside of the screen after dying. Besides to that, well done.
Thanks for the comments so far, folks. The feedback is very much appreciated. I'm doing a post-competition build, and feedback is very welcome. Expect an upload in the next couple of days :).
The tuning is pretty off in this competition build, you're absolutely right Draknek.
Like the style, like the gameplay, like how hectic it is, not sure how it relates to the theme but feel you've got a great game concept to expand on here!

Vieko Franetovic- Ah, the lack of tutorial is probably not working in my favor here! Sorry about any confusion. It's possible to destroy enemy castles and steal their components. Once we destroy an enemy base, we can run over its components and take them home. Once we're there, the components can be placed with the mouse.
I'm happy to announce that I've got a first public post-competition build up here:
I'm still actively developing this, and there will be more builds to come.

I like the general idea of your game, but I was a bit disappointed by the method of assaulting enemy castles. It seems to be mostly the same thing every time. Run in with your one ship, and circle strafe repeatedly.

Here's my idea for attacking enemy castles. You can take it or leave it or modify it. (Some) buildings produce units. Once you've built up some units, you can give orders to a group of them (such as attack a castle), but cannot control them directly. If your units defeat a castle, then you can plunder their buildings and technology (new unit types, for example).
Good work, and it's nice to see that you're doing more with this post-competition. Thanks for your comment on my entry!
Fun game, made me want to play again when I died.

description:
This is my Entry for the Competition, It's a little minimalist, and might be glitchy, but I hope people enjoy it :D.
Arcane has been bit of a blur really, I had an original idea I wanted to go with, but realised that I would run out of time before I could get that submitted. As a result, halfway through the contest I had to swap over to this concept. I hope the Spectrum-like Charm appeals to folks here :).
EDIT - Now with fixed Battle Mode :D (I Hope)
EDIT 2 - Now includes Source File.
author: Neonlare
title: ARCANE
comments: The graphics are definitely old-school. I found it really difficult to aim, however - since you can only rotate in the eight cardinal directions, it makes it very difficult to hit enemies, especially when they're somewhat small. The mechanic for picking up enemy shot types was a little hard for the same reason, but it was a good idea.
The inclusion of multiplayer is great. I didn't get to test it since nobody's around in the wee hours of the morning, but the it's pretty neat that you included it at all.
Also, don't forget to include your source code!
Yeah, I don't get it. So you get the power of an enemy that you manage to kill? Saying that somewhere would be good. Nice aesthetic, but hard to play.
The focus of the game primarily is multiplayer, I should have added in the notepad what each of the enemy spells give, their charge and damage, I'm sorry for missing that out.

As for the aiming, I can fix that, but I'm not sure if it'll be allowed through because it'd be after the deadline. It'd be rigged to the cardinal directions, so only 8 directions as opposed to the "swing" you can get from this, but that means more stable aiming.
I'll be sure to address these issues and more if I make an updated and improved version/sequel to this.

description:
Basically you have just warped into a field of asteroids, you cant win, but your going to try your best to stay alive! (high score game)
Use WSAD or the arrow keys to move, space bar to activate your tractor beam, but beware you only have so much energy and shields
made with love2d (yea I said I was going to use processing, but then the theme ended up being a game mechanic and I needed to manage a ton of objects at once, love2d has a physics engine, processing doesn't)
Windows, download the windows version and double click, Nix and mac must download and install love2d from love2d.org, and download the love file above (marked as linux)
Its been a fun time, and good luck to everyone
PS: requires a 1024x768 screen (though the game is windowed, it was setup to fit the game + window on 1014x768, barley)
author: Osgeld
title: Your Doomed
comments: Nicely done.  Does the game get harder over time? I played to about 200 by pushing everything off the right of the screen, so I never had any asteroids onscreen for long.

it is a little buggy in that regard box 2d is weird like that, even though there is zero gravity and zero friction if you jumble them up too much things start to stick though I apply impulses, and I fussed with it for nearly a day (not amused)
and yea it does get faster over time, as long as the non existant friction and gravity dont take hold
Needed a bit more to do; would have been nice to have less asteroids and maybe some aliens shooting at you that you needed to crush with the rocks?
Otherwise interesting mechanically and has potential, perhaps.

I noticed that if you spam the space bar you'll be able to grab the same rock several times and accelerate it so much that doing this a few times can clear the screen of rocks.. this was a little buggy. i did like the game otherwise :)

Not too bad of an idea, but I thought the controls could be better, more direct, and it would probably be better if the effect of a thrown meteor was more obvious. This way you might clear the way, or maybe not. Explosions maybe? Or is that too clichÃ©?

description:
Full title: "Wherein obstacles should be avoided and thereafter repurposed as weapons - IN SPACE"
Sadly has no sound at all.
author: Salt
title: Wherein Obstacles [...] IN SPACE
comments: Very nice looking. Kind of ran out of steam when there can be several seconds between missiles appearing. Could've herded them to the gunship, but only did it once.
Good game but the phase is too slow as Pokute says. I liked the 3D though
Nice looking game! I think like the missile impact effects could have used a bit more oomph though.
realllly slow on my laptop (2.4ghz macbook)
Great graphics, but the jerky scrolling kinda belied the space-theme.  Really slick missile tracking, it was fun to "drag" them around gravitationally with the ship.  Wished I could fire back!

Fantastic shader work, Salt - we both put in entries with Pixel Bender stuff... yay!  I think the gameplay could have had more balancing, and collision seemed a bit unpredictabe, but you have the makings of a great looking shooter here - nice work!
Very nice graphics but somehow not performing very good here.
Besides the awesome graphics the game feels kinda plain.
The terrible framerate rendered it basicaly unplayable for me :(
Very nice graphics, but perhaps you could notch up the action a bit.
Looks cool, but I'm not going to be able to rate it as it's unplayably slow on my machine (2.4 GHz P4). Looks like 5 FPS or so.
It was also unplayable for me, looking more like a slideshow than a game. 1.6Ghz Thinkpad.
Great looking, but it seemed jerky and slow even on my 2.4GHz quad-core with an NVidia 9600... also agree that the action was a little lacking.
Looks like a good base for fun shooter though, well done!
I am disappointed that you cannot use missiles to shoot down gunships. :(

description:
The South and the North suck yorkshire puddings! I'm from the Midlands me! is a harmless madlibs type creation centered on a fictional war between Northern and Southern England.
You play a couple of generals from the Midlands who decide to compile propaganda to encourage the North and the South to wage war on each other, rather than you.
There are four possible endings try and get them all :)
No offence is intended through this game and it was all made in good fun, I myself am from the South of England, and my partner is from the North, and find the game entertaining by many standards.
Made with Game Maker 8.
Also @greasemonkey's comment, I was not under the influence when I was making this game, just overly tired, I'm quite please with what my result was considering I was working the whole of sunday and so only made it in about 20 or so hours.
Oh yes, and graphically it is supposed to look pants, I'm not an artist, maybe you might see it as charming... I don't.
Oh, and be warned there is some swearing involved in the game, and some rude outcomes, I was going to make it a little more friendly, but I did not have the extra time.
author: cptalbertwesker
title: The South and the North suck yorkshire puddings! I'm from the Midlands me!
comments: This is a perfect example of why Game Maker sucks SO HORRIBLY under Wine.
It's a funny concept, but it makes me think that it would be even better if you could just insert a pic of yourself in there and play as "you".

Awesome game, it's extremely simple but works well, I'd love to see a more expanded version with more insults, and like devinmoore said if you could put yourself in it that'd be awesome, like photo dojo but less fighting more insulting :)
Actually, scrub what I said, it runs a lot better in Wine 1.2-rc3 compared to 1.1.32.
This is the game in 1.1.32: http://i34.tinypic.com/b4vnfd.jpg
Is this complete? I tried doing a sentence, it announces it fine, but nothing seems to happen.

Lol, what a weird idea. Was surprised that it only took one comment to win the game, but you could easily expand it if you wanted. Sure, there's not a lot of content in the game, but it's a nice idea and wonderfully silly. Well done ;)
I just get a screen saying "choose a word", then it crashes. Win 7 64bit.
@Danik I'm using Win 7 64bit also and it ran fine for me
I think GreaseMonkey meant this wine (http://www.winehq.org/), not the drink :)

description:
Arrow keys move.
Up, z, or c to jump.
X or space to pick up the guy you are standing on.
X or space again to throw.
You can touch the tops but not the sides or bottom of the enemies.
STAY ALIVE FOR SIXTY SECONDS
Note: You aren't getting pulled toward the center, the camera is catching up to you.
author: ExciteMike
title: Survive 60
comments: It was a fun, yet short game that stayed somewhat challenging all the way through, good job! The background was also very nice, but my one complaint is the audio. I know it kind of fit in, but after a while it just got annoying!
great visuals in the back there, concept was kind of obvious but the game feels good to play.
I have weird input issues where the guy sometimes seems to want to drift towards the middle. Is that intentional? I'm not sure it adds a lot to the gameplay and it feels wrong.
Background is cool but doesn't really fit with the game.
Down as an alternate key for picking up enemies would be nice.
Challenging, great, minimalistic. You know what this is? The perfect realization of `Enemies as Weapons'.
And with gratuitous fractals, too. Yum.

Great work.  I like the screensaver in the background.  The one counter-intuitive thing is that because the background is fixed in place it never feels like I'm moving.  Coupled with the magnetic camera and the whole time it felt like I wasn't in control.  Overall, a really atmospheric, quality game.  Keep up the great work!
I enjoyed playing this one. The concept wasn't anything too new, but it was executed nicely. I liked the background, but yeah, it didn't really fit. All in all if was fun, though.
Nice, eerie atmosphere in this game. Good gameplay aswell, minimalistic but fun. Nice Work!
Cute little minigame, just enough challenging. I played for quite some time but only managed to get down to 12 seconds :).

Really playable - I like the atmospheric music and the player sprite animation too, simple but effective. The 'autocentering' mechanic works really well for a quick little challenge like this. Agree that the trippy screensaver background doesn't fit the rest of the game, despite maybe being a bit of fun to make technically. I also found it weird that the jump sound seemed to trigger at the apex of a jump rather than perfectly synchronized with the button press - you get used to it, but it seemed a bit wrong at first.
Great prototype, nice style too. Could use some more polish and detailing. Quite fun, but I couldn't beat it.

description:
Tag the stupid squares by pressing LEFT SHIFT and then make them explode by holding LEFT SHIFT near one of them.
Tagging consumes your health (the more squares are near you, the more health you lose), but you can gain it back by eating the "pills" they leave behind when they explode.
Not as fun as I would have liked it to be, but still playable. Maybe you can create an interesting map yourself!
Thanks to Lanael for the FreeBSD build.
author: stqn
title: Stupid Squares
comments: Sounds interesting, but can't play it :(
I'm on win xp sp3; the menu appears, select map and window closes.
Oops :( I'll see if I can reproduce the problem...

Well, I unzipped the game on the desktop under Win XP SP2, launched ld18.exe by clicking on it, and everything worked as expected... There is no error message in the MSDOS window that opens under the game, when it closes itself?
Mmm.. so blame it on my system. AV is down, permissions granted... :(

description:
You have entered the RoboColosseum's greatest challenge: the never-ending cannon swarm so intent on your destruction they fire their own comrades at you, thus your enemies are weapons that are used by other enemies! Armed with nothing but the ability to create walls, you must destroy as many enemy robots as possible. Bonus points apply for acting the destructo-cannonball yourself! Can you beat the high score?
If you do like this game, the graphics look noticeably better in fullscreen and it's easier to figure out what's going on, so please, go ahead and download it :D
The source is essentially the entire unity project folder, with some bonus raw files for art and music - point unity at it and go
author: Toeofdoom
title: Robocolosseum
comments: Interesting take on the theme.  I was entertained that it was a valid, though not a very good, strategy to ride a wall up and walk on a path of walls.
Yeah, I figured it was strange that it was possible, but it didn't break anything or work very well so I left it as is. :)
I love the way this looks - the cool colours, the robots and especially the walls as they get chipped away.
On my first attempt I thought I had to get the robots to shoot each other. Later on I worked out that I could damage them just by placing walls.

Absolutely, there are a few ways to get rid of robots. You can even block off spawns in advance if you feel like it (spawns activate one by one until all 4 are going 2 minutes in, at which point it's constant)
I love the story and the graphic style you used, and it an  original game overall.
This is pretty bizarre! I like the interpretation, and it's got a nice Terminator feel to it. Definitely needs a cheering robot crowd.
Wonderful graphics, original concept, and absolutely freaking awesome piano music you made for this!  I am extremely impressed.  Keep up the fabulous work!
Thanks for the support guys, it's awesome when at least a few people actually enjoy a game instead of tolerating it. :D Hopefully I can keep making games that way.

I seem to be the only one posting here to say this, but I really don't get what I'm supposed to do. I played the web version, and maybe there's something missing there. Are the things that fly towards me supposed to look like enemy bodies? That might have been a bug.
I think maybe the camera should be pulled back so that I can tell what I'm doing, and apart from that maybe a clearer explanation or a video of the game in action.
It sounds like a cool idea, and I love the setting, but I'm at a loss as to what to do :(

You may be the only one here to say that, but people elsewhere have definitely said the same thing. Essentially, theme is enemies as weapons... for other enemies. So they have cannons on top and actually fire each other at you - it's no bug. :)

I've found that it's easier to tell what's happening in fullscreen mode, but you might be quite right about the camera. I haven't really thought about that. Another part of the problem is that when the robots get fired they "jump" straight to the cannon, not moving smoothly at all.
I had to laugh when I saw alistair's comment, because I was thinking exactly the same thing when I played it. Then I quit and read your description above, and it made a lot more sense!

description:
To compile under Ubuntu, make sure you've got SDL devel packages and run make. To exit the game press q. Otherwise, pretty straight forward tower defense-type game. Let me know how it goes!
Windows port now available!
author: jakkarth
title: Recycling Defense
comments: I'd consider putting  in some more ingame documentation, such as how much the towers cost, as well as the 'press q to quit' instruction.  Nice pathfinding.
Seems like any other tower defense game, im sorry. could do with better graphics, too.

Good polished entry. But, the game was very easy to beat and was too short. Also it didn't make much use of the different weapon types in a compelling way (it was possible to beat the game only with fireball towers).
Not really sure what this had to do with the theme.

Not a bad idea for a tower defense game, I guess. What bugged me though is that I was never really required to use any of the "enemies as weapons" weapons, because the basic little peashooters would kill everything if I built a labyrinth.

I also had a bit of trouble understanding how exactly the spud cannons and converters worked because there was no visual showing me when they were absorbing enemies. I also didn't understand how the weapons on the right worked, much for the same reason.
You should really do something about the cannons all firing in unison. It sounds terrible and looks kinda boring.
Please don't name your zip just "ld18.zip" :)

It's quite annoying to lose when the first enemy reaches the house. The first level is a bit too hard, you have to place a lot of fire-spewing things to kill the enemies. Once I did that, I didn't get a chance to use the "enemies as weapons" weapons for the next three levels because all enemies were dying by fire before reaching the new weapons.
And then I lost because I had put an ice cube on the path just in front of the saucer and that blocked the enemies and the chrono went to zero.

description:
A fairly simple arcade puzzler, where you have to possess zombies and then use their abilities as weapons.
Linux and Windows have been tested to work with Java Web Start (JRE 6 required).
Just a clarification of the controls:
ARROWS: Move
SPACE: Fire ability (most abilities take some time to work
so you need to hold it down)
author: mwest
title: Rainbow Hero
comments: Would you please upload the files to some place that doesn't require creating an account to download? Thank you.
when I click the links it says 'documents not available'.
Download is  broken. Let me know if you fix it so I can test this out (thelastbanana@hotmail.com).
Sorry about that, I've changed the sharing permissions so that it should be accessible without creating an account now.
Hopefully I can sort out my the PHP file upload size limit on my hosting account soon so that I can do away with using Google docs completely...
Ok, sorted out my hosting - everything is now direct links... so you should be able to access it now!
This warms my heart with how much it reminded me of Wolfenstein.  And usage of zombie rainbows is a nice touch, but it just doesn't seem to be that close to the theme from what I saw.
How do I explode the red haired zombies? I tried every key on my keyboard.

Double ZOMBIE Rainbow for the wiiiiin!  You gotta love the joke theme here - thanks for incorporating my silly bit of photoshopping into the game.  I'm giving you a few free bonus points just for having fun with the non-theme.  Well done!  Rainbow ray!!!
Thanks Breakdance McFunkypants - glad you enjoyed it!!
@Danik - you use the SPACE BAR, but you have to hold it in for a second or two... maybe I should document that better or give better cues (audio as well instead of just visual).
Just added a Java Web Start release of the game, which I've tested to confirm that it work on Windows & Linux :).
@mwest Ah, I didn't hold it for long enough. Yea, defenitely give better clues. Maybe you could make the zombie start shaking earlier.

Glad the download is up now. The game was quite fun! At first it was a little annoying that you only have one life bar through the whole game, but now that I see how long it is, I think that was actually a pretty good decision. The graphics were obviously not award-winning, but they worked, and so long as I could tell the difference between the zombie types (which I could), it's fine. The title screen image of double rainbow zombies is hilarious, although I have to wonder if you have rights to that image.

I liked this game, I think you could make it into a good puzzle game. Well done with the tutorial and progressive progression (or whatever); the only problem I had was finding how to make zombies do their thing (press space for a long time, which isn't documented).
Oh and I first downloaded the linux package but I couldn't run the .jar, so I used the web start thing which worked very well.
Not being a fan of the DoubleRainbowZombie theme, I had low expectations for this game. However, it had a solid mechanic that fitted the EAW theme nicely.

description: This is a game about something, but I'll leave it to you to interpret.  I'm not happy with some of the text, but it was very rushed.  I think that payoff was ok, though.
author: superflat
title: Psychic Prison Break
comments: ugh, i'm really not a fan of "lots of text" games, and not only that, this really doesn't execute it well, so double whammy for innovation and fun
graphics are excellent but UGH I'M SICK OF FLIXEL/FLASHPUNK WHY OH WHY DON'T PEOPLE JUST LEARN A REAL LANGUAGE (this coming from the guy who made a first person shooter in megazeux)
there's a hint of the theme but it really doesn't seem to come through, plus from what i've played they're not actually weapons, sorry
audio is there and it works
not sure if this really has humour, maybe it's a bit dry, so N/A (1 star is for really awful humour)
overall, this game isn't dreadful, but it's not really that great either
you posted a few screenshots so i can give you that for community, at least you have posts (other than just "i'm starting" and "yay i've finished")
Obviously Greasemonkey is a massive troll, so please ignore him.
I was really impressed with how well this came together. Very imaginative and surprising, it's a great interpretation of the theme.  Love the art style too. Congratulations!
I really like this. You nailed the art-game pixel-grunge aesthetic, right down to the lo-fi audio -- I only wish there was more to it!
Or maybe there is, and I can't figure it out. Maybe?

Brilliant design on the walk-off splash screen.  Great graphics for the concept.  Technical notes: games that make me choose what to say and have big nebulous plots that evolve based on what I say are confusing.  I just wanted to find a key and get out of there and explore some more, which is both good and bad... good because it means the game environment is very inviting, but bad because I didn't have the patience to deal with the talking-to in order to get there.
Thanks for the kind comments (although I appreciate the length of GreaseMonkey's, the feedback was ... odd!)

Anyway, Doches, It is possible to escape the prison, so it might be worth persevering!  A hint is to try and follow the path of a conversation until you see a visible change in the prisoner's appearance, then try a different tack.
Excellent job.  The ending was really moody... in a good way.  The atmosphere was brilliantly achieved.

It seems that you are able to press 'up' to move your selected topic above the screen (pressing up twice requires pressing down twice to get it back onscreen), and trying to select an offscreen option crashes the game. Perhaps it's an index out of bounds thing?
First I was kinda stuck, felt I'm doing something wrong. then I finally got the hang. It's more of an interactive-story than a game but still I like it. Too bad it was that short.

Great vibe, nice intro screen, original concept.  I found the button pressed we'rent "debounced" meaning sometimes I double-skipped a message or held X down a fraction of a second too long and a prompt came and went.  Pretty cool: keep up the great work.  I'd love to see this expanded some more.  Frankly though I like the gfx you need more pixels, the font is really hard to read.  Overall, great job.

description:
My entry is called "Protractor", it's a katamari shmup!  You WILL need the latest version of DirectX!  Update if you see a missing dll errors.  I also put up a link to an enhanced version with some post-deadline bug fixes and gameplay tweaks.  Enjoy!
Gameplay Help
- Kill enemies and collect their parts to build.
- Use left mouse to pull parts to you to attach them.
- Colors indicate health level.  Purple is super high health, red is about to die.  Your ship will auto recharge health but other parts wont, unless you have a healer attached.
- Weapons are randomized but all have the same DPS so on average they will cause the same amount of damage. Larger bullets represent more damage.
- Try to keep your ship balanced or it will become difficult to control.  Use engine placement to help balance things out.
- Triangle - Weapon (random but normalized to the same DPS)
- Square - Healer (auto repairs ship and attached parts)
- Pentagon - Speed Booster (increases speed and turn rate)
- Circle - Extender (allows for expansion)
Controls
- Left mouse - Move parts
- Spacebar or Right mouse - Shoot
- WASD - Move your ship
- Alt+Enter - Go fullscreen (recommended)
Tools Used
- Visual C++ 2010 Express
- Frank Engine (my open source game engine)
- Box2d physics
- SFXR and Audacity for sound effects
- GIMP for image editing
- Tortoise SVN for revision control
author: KilledByAPixel
title: Protractor
comments: Beautiful visuals and intuitive gameplay. It was a pleasure bulking up my behemoth spreadshot ship, then watching it get blown apart. The object placement controls could use refinement, and the audio is grating. Otherwise, it's a really impressive effort.
Love the visuals!, didn't like so much how hard it was to gather parts and how easy it was to lose them.

It is very pretty, you have the graphics for this sort of thing down to a tea.   The gameplay is there, but needs a lot of tuning.   Baddies take a lot to take down, and the tractor / attach system is confusing...  Audio is passable and servicable, but bland.
A very nice idea that looks wonderful. Clean and simple. Fresh, interesting and polished.

If there's one issue I have with the game it's that the controls are too awkward. There's just too many things to think about. Which way is my ship pointing, where is my cursor, having to manually pull ship parts onto the ship... there's just too much to handle. Some of it would probably be best done automatically. Maybe ship parts should gravitate towards you, instead of having to follow the mouse, and you could find some other way to rearrange the ship parts.
Overall, a wonderfully fresh and polished game, which is very fun despite its drawbacks :)

Thanks!  I'm glad everyone is digging the visuals and understanding how to play.  I agree about controls being an issue.  I experimented with them somewhat during the comp but in the interest of time I decided to go with the simplest solution.

The tractor beam controls are something I want to work on.  Right now it's just a simple spring system but I think I can improve that so it controls more tightly.  I like idea of them gravitating in.  Maybe you there's a new part that sucks other parts to it?  I'm also thinking about allowing the player to select multiple objects at once with the tractor beam to speed up part placement.

description:
The goal is to shoot the orange dots back at the other orange dots to kill them.
Source included with download
author: Sakar
title: Orange Dots of DOOM!!1!11

description:
Fact is it's not finished, it's not close to finished either. Controls are:
WASD to move
E to summon a bunny
Arrow keys to move the bunny
F to attack with the bunny
Q to damage the wizard (debugging for life)
Space to pause the knight so he's not up in your grill
What's in:
> Graphics, sprites and blitting
> Sound, sound manager for all your beeps and boops
> Input, rather necessary
> Ultra basic "AI"
What's not in:
> Title screen
> Collisions
> Damage
> Scoring system
> Swarms of enemies
> Summon upgrades
Essentially, I literally just finished University and have never finished a project, I wasn't sure if I'd finish this or not but I thought what the hell, what have I got to lose by entering. So in my opinion, not a bad effort but that's all it was, an effort, not a game =P ah well, better luck to me next time :)
author: Attecus
title: Ol' Conjurer
comments: It doesn't start for me, I guess I need something installed? What do I need?
Had to download two DLL's from the internet:
Googled for them and works just fine
Ah, sorry about that guys, thanks for the fix Darkhogg, I'll remember to fix that in the next jam. Thanks to both for checking out my humble unfinished "game"
Mind packing in a copy of the MSVC redistributable with your game?
Windows build re-upped with MSVC 2010 re-distributable =) sorry for the issues everyone's having
You know it dude =P this game was going places... To bad it never got there >.<
doesn't start here, even after installing the VC redist.
It makes the bunny attack sound if you press f with no bunny summoned.
vc_redist is not fixing the missing "MSVCR100D.DLL " problem for me :(
You compiled the game in debug mode. That is not covered by the redist package (note the d on the end of the dll). You need to use release mode.

description: You have the power to make enemies explode with but a thought. Can you escape the 12 levels and become the Master Exploder?
author: hcs
title: Master Exploder
comments: Best LD18 entry yet. Clever idea, clever puzzles. Want more!

Innovation: I love the idea! It's pretty awesome, mind-controlled bombs and bombs that can feel your mind-control and auto-explode! Oh my! The only way you could go better than this is if you made a NES rom for the compo!
Fun: It's frustrating, but not the "frustrating gragh" one, but the "fun frustration" one. I enjoyed playing it, both the less finished version with placeholder graphics and this one.
Theme: I don't see why it doesn't fit the theme, it's pretty good!
Graphics: Not the best, but quite nice nontheless!
Humor: The end screen made me smile, and the last level was annoying so much it made me laugh. 3/5.
Overall: A sharp 4/5. Great idea, lots of fun, but it's lacking in the audio department. And the graphics could be improved.

description:
Hello! Me and my friend Pete made this game below in 70ish hours, from scratch in Delphi.
MARCH OF THE RORGERS - HOW TO PLAY
==================================
PREMISE
-------
Bobbing up and down at the top of the screen is the blue Orb. Defend it at all costs. It is surrounded by four laser towers which provide some limited defence. HOWEVER! Those towers alone are nowhere near powerful enough on their own to halt the march of the Rorgers. Instead, you will have to rely on the building abilities of the little crab-like Builder Bot sitting in your base. The key is to turn the enemies against each other. Here's how:
BUILD MENU
----------
Commands are executed mainly through the Build Menu, which is accessed by clicking anywhere on the terrain (except for the Orb). There are three types of command, and executing multiple commands in quick succession will cause the commands to be queued up.
-SALVAGE-
Your Builder Bot is capable of collecting resources from the land. Rocks and buildings can be salvaged by clicking on them in the terrain and selecting the 'GET' icon. Resources are important; without them there's only a limited amount that you can build. You can see how many you have in the top right corner of the screen.
-SIGNS-
Your bot is capable of building four types of signs pointing up, down, left and right. Each sign costs 10 resources and you may only build 3 signs per builder bot you have in your possession. Click where you would like to build and the build menu will appear. Select the sign you want from it, and your bot will go to work.
A sign may not be placed directly near another sign; when the build menu is up you will see a red radius around locations where you cannot build.
-DESTROY-
Clicking on a sign and then the hammer icon will send your Builder Bot to destroy it, for when it is no longer useful or you need to free up sign slots.
THE ORB
-------
The Orb that you are guarding is a special case, as clicking on it gives you the chance to build an extra Builder Bot. Having extra builders is good because it increases your sign limit and allows more commands to be executed simultaneously, but it comes at the relatively hefty price of 50 resources.
THE RORGERS
-----------
There are 3 different types of Rorgers; Stress Rorgers (Red), Envy Rorgers (Green) and Fear Rorgers (Black). All have the common goal of destroying your Orb but different types of Rorgers do not get along. You must use this to your advantage by guiding them into conflict with each other via the signs you build.
Rorgers begin at the bottom of the screen, emerging from their deployment tubes, and work their way upward before converging on your base.
Signs will cause Rorgers to change direction when encountered, but they will not be fooled forever. After a while, unless they encounter another sign they will realise they have been led astray and head back towards your orb.
IMPORTANT: Each Rorger will only be fooled by the same sign once, so don't expect the same trick to work twice.
You can see on the right side of the screen a chart that indicates which type of Rorger will attack which. But be warned: this may change occasionally as a result of the volatile Rorger political situation that is beyond our comprehension.
TIP: Be wary of those sneaky Fear Rorgers - they like to attack your base from the sides!
---
Good Luck, and we hope you enjoy the game!
Love from,
Surprised Man
author: Spleeny
title: March of the Rorgers
comments: Good job guys! Heard you on the NZCast and upon seeing you had no comments I thought I'd give you one, Congrats!

Thanks, able_to_think! We're really happy with it and we're definitely planning on moving onto bigger and better projects. Glad you enjoyed the NZCast. I was very self-conscious of how tired and groggy we both were during those recordings :)

description:
This is my first ever entry to Ludum Dare! HypnoFruit is a tower defense game, where your use captured creeps as towers. To use a creep as a tower you must first defeat it, then feed it enough hypnofruit.
I didnÃ¢ï¿½ï¿½t have as much time as I wanted to, so the graphics are horrible, and there are only two barely tested levels. I did manage to get a few sound effects in before I ran out of time. Overall, I had a pretty good experience, without any serious setbacks.
author: Alan Lynn
title: HypnoFruit (TD)
comments: Good idea, it's just too bad there's only the two levels. On the second level, I got so many of the cockroaches that by the time I had enough fruit to deploy the first boss, he had been pushed off the list :(
Anyway, you should consider expanding this after the compo. It was fun!
Does not seem to run under Wine.
I'll give it a try sometime after I've rebooted into Windows.
This is a good idea. I like the combination of growing trees and placing turrets. I agree that an expanded post-competition version would be worthwhile.
Pretty nicely done, but as you pointed out yourself it would be much better with more work. Still, it was fun.
I'd like to play a full scale tower defence like this :)
I had the same problem as TheLastBanana. I was unable to use the yellow boss. Also, I was a bit bummed that the game was just two levels. I only had just got the hang of it.

The Help screen could use some pictures. I didn't want to read it and so it took me a moment to figure out the game by myself. I never quite understood what function there was in planting apples on the ground. The trees are income and the roaches are turrets, but what are the apples for other than cash?

author: ippa
title: GNORF
comments: I really liked the idea of the game! Nice Work. :)
Fun! I love that you've got a high score table, though I'm having problems getting into it - got to level 5 so far!
It also quits (crash?) when I die (downloaded windows version today).
@TomBom: that crash should be fixed since yesterday.. are you _sure_ you got the new ippa.se/games/gnorf.exe ? Cause I had that problem too before, but since the fix, I've never seen it.
@Covenant: tnx, did you take a high score? =)
@someone: Try it now! Was out for 1 hour while I fixed the crashbug!
Fun game! I made a highscore but when entering my name, I accidentally moved one step left from the A, selecting GO instead. I'm "D". :P
Danik: hah, ok =). That's decent high score!
Nice!  I wish I could restart at the level I failed, though, instead of going all the way back to the start.

description:
Exterminate! Exterminate!
INSTRUCTIONS (please read, the game isn't really self explanatory):
So you have to destroy all the robots to go to the next level. But you can't harm the robots directly only friendly fire can destroy them.
So try to go in the middle and dodge when they fire. If only one robot is left, jump to your death, you need to restart the level. Also note that they have a tendency to synchronize their firing which can help you.
Also note that the later levels are very hard so don't feel bad if you can't beat the game (11 levels total).
author: Codexus
title: Exterminate 48
comments: The game played well, and everything worked as it should. My only real problem was that I found the AI to be more random than anything. Almost every time I lost, it felt less like I had messed up and more like "why didn't that robot shoot like it normally does?" If the AI were a bit more consistent, solving the puzzles would have felt like less of a game of chance.
Either way, for 48 hours of work, it's great. Thanks for the game :)

Good gameplay. I'll admit I intentionally got shot a few times after I heard the death noise! Nothing too revolutionary in terms of mechanic, but nicely implemented. The background was a little dizzying, adding to the challenge. Nice work!
Fun, although I got stuck in level 7 or 8... The backgrounds were gorgeous, how did you do them? Pre-rendered or procedurally generated?
Definitely a stronger entry. I love the look and feel of the game. A bit simplistic, and I got stuck because the tanks need to be perfectly timed (if there is one tank left, you lose the level).

The sound effects and particles/backgrounds are excellent. I like the character animation too, as well as the tanks. A little more cleanup in gameplay and this would be a great game. Also: Maybe some powerups, or collectible items?

Really nice! Simple but effective. I agree with LastBanana about the seemingly random AI, and I didn't get far through before getting stuck (also about level 6 or 7). But fun, simple and clean. A great accomplishment, well done!
LOOKS AMAZING. It's a bit slow and cumbersome, but that's me being REALLY nit-picky, as what you have is quite impressive.
You get an extra star for allowing me to stand on a Dalek's head. :)
@TheLastBanana: The AI is actually fully deterministic but I guess it can be a bit hard to predict if you're not the one who wrote the code.

description:
This game has been designed for and tested on the iPad.  It should also work on iPhone, though that has not been tested.
If you don't have access to either of those devices, it is playable, but slightly degraded, on mozilla and webkit-based browsers.
author: kd5bjo
title: Dodger
comments: sfernald: Your browser has a "View Source" button somewhere.
Alternatively, right-click on the "Source" link here, save it to your hard drive, and open it with a text editor.
haha, ok, that makes sense. I thought it was flash. I was wondering how it would work on a iphone. I'll try it on my ipad and let you know how it goes...
Not bad. It was somewhat easy and slow paced; the difficulty didn't seem to increase very much.
Don't have any Apple products, but this is the kind of game I'd catch myself playing from time to time on my phone.

I do feel like the game needs more incentive for playing well... as it is, slowly wiping out turrets one at a time (spending as little time in the cross-fire as possible) is a more effective strategy than dashing into the midst of things and trying to wipe them out quickly.
Could have been great fun but was too slow. I didn't feel like I had much control over where the enemies were shooting, as I spent most of my time just waiting for them to face me.
Nice try, and there is the germ of a good game in here, but for your next version you should (a) make it so that the guns spin faster, or (b) make it so the guns always face the player.
I agree with posters saying it's a bit too slow and easy to be fun - apart from that a good entry!
I've seen a few tempt-enemies-to-shoot-each-other games and although the rotational mechanic in this one was an innovation, the game was just a little too slow to keep interest.
Turrets rotate too slowly for this to be much fun.
I also would have expected the guy to move to where I click, rather than moving a set distance in that direction and then stopping.
Not bad, but the game was a bit to slow paced to have any real challenge
Didn't work in Opera, everything spawned at 0,0.
