I was looking forward to playing this game, ever since I saw the screenshot on the blog. It was just as good as I expected.
Tthe first two enemies I dispatched using fire, ice and wind, and I couldn't quite figure out how it was related to the theme. However, I then froze an enemy and blew it into another one!

I love the subtle animation of the main character, and the little touches that made me smile (the rabbits running faster when they're on fire, fire melting the ice). All it's missing is a story and/or some levels. Overall, though, really well done!

ok, keybindings are arse and what's with this flixel/flashpunk fad it's really flippin' wrong, if you're going to make a pixelly game use something else, flash is for ads which use vector art and suck the utter crap out of your bandwidth
also the keys are backwards GRR
i like how you have multiple spells, that is *quite* a nice touch
it would be much more fun if it were faster
i didn't really see the theme being played clearly in this, but apparently it exists, i'm reading your journal so i'll just have to take your word for it
overall, quite promising, but as it stands it's kinda drab with respect to gameplay, next time don't spend so much damn time on the graphics

community effort is pretty lacking, which is usually quite understandable due to not having enough effort left, but a couple of screenshots and jotting down notes is something i would consider reasonable.
I like the graphics. Yeah, without levels there's not much to do. Though setting things on fire is fun.

" what's with this flixel/flashpunk fad it's really flippin' wrong, if you're going to make a pixelly game use something else, flash is for ads which use vector art and suck the utter crap out of your bandwidth "

This doesn't seem like a fair criticism at all. Flash is for many different things, and flixel offers a good SDL style method, especially as people are getting used to Flex. I hope you're not going to criticise every low-resolution flash game here.

The only reason this isn't 5 stars is that I can't tell what spells I'm using.  the gameplay has a whymsical humor to it, similar to the fun cute-ness of the mario franchise's specialty levels.  Great work.

Great graphics. I didn't see a way to know what was going to happen when I hit Z, an indicator of which spell I was going to cast would be nice. A few minutes with sfxr could have been helpful, but the graphics made up for it. Nice work!

I liked the colors you chose for the game, it looks nice and seems to work nicely but i really wanted to have some more content for the game. Overall id say you got still quite alot of things done in 48 hours and everything feels polished.
Really cool art and a pretty fun game. I would like to have seen an icon or something to show which spell I'm using though. And some sounds would really spice things up
I really like the graphics. Fun little thing to mess around with =P

description:
FAIL-DEADLY designed and developed by Josh Sutphin.
More stuff: http://www.third-helix.com
So this is basically a simple RTS where you play as both sides.
I took a loose interpretation of the "Enemies As Weapons" theme: you are a shadowy third party using two enemies against each other to achieve some secret, grander goal.
Incidentally, this is the first indie game I've ever designed that contains blood. So that's a thing. :P
author: Deadly
title: Fail
comments: Oh good. I posted this and then my web host promptly went offline. Trying to get it resolved now... if the download links don't work for you, try it again in a bit.
Looks like we're back up so that's yay.
Wow, this is really great. good job.
I didn't expect the momentum swings, it made quite an exciting attack-and-counterattack
It's very fun to play. Good job! The main flaw is that it seems that there is not always a good reason to keep placing buildings, it will only make it harder on yourselves.
Loved it! It took 3 plays to win and even the ones where I lost were fun! After winning I wished for more levels :P

@Jhelle Yeah, of the things that didn't make the deadline, that's probably the one I'm most bothered by. I was thinking of triggering an airstrike to destroy some random stuff if you hold out too long, thus forcing you to work to rebalance the system again.
I'll patch it in after the compo. :)

Very cool! The first game I played went smoothly (though I did have to pay attention to keep the balance), but the next three times I tried it was so unbalanced that I had no chance. Lots of fun when in the groove!
I loved this game! It was very immersive. Only wish there was more levels. :]
One of the better entries!! Very, very slick presentation, superb concept and interpretation of theme, and fun to boot.
Trying to think of ways to take this further... maybe a 3-way multiplayer game, each player with a different, secret goal, all trying to influence the outcome of battling AI armies.....

I had a blast playing and my two sons did as well. I think the "Air Strike" feature that is mentioned above would enhance it even further. And or a randomly spawned "Boss" style character to add some extra chaos into the mix.
A few of you have mentioned the desire for more levels. What do you mean by that?
- Different battlefield layouts with chokepoints, cover, etc. so that each level is more of a unique map?
- Different victory/failure conditions, so that each level is more of a puzzle?
- Different sets of available buildings and units?
- Other things I'm failing to realize?
Very cool game, clever use of the theme, and also fun to play! Wish the graphics were a bit better though... very impressive for such a short contest, and cool gameplay.
-chokepoints, cover like mountains or bodies of water where only certain enemies can pass.
-make one teamâ��s units always weaker than the other
-make certain units really strong for a whole match (i.e. Super Soldiers)

description:
Arrow keys to move, click to shoot. You have only limited ammo, but you can replenish it by collecting the carcasses of enemy ships.
Made with C++ and SFML.
Windows versions provided by Monk. (Thanks, Monk!)
The current version has minor changes to the original submitted version. It no longer segfaults at wave 7, the time resets when you die, rendering is faster (probably not noticeable for anyone else, but it is for me), and ammo count is not printed to stdout (I forgot to remove that originally).
There's a bug which causes sounds to stop playing after a while, and not return until you quit. There's another which causes bullets to only show up intermittently after a while, which can be "fixed" by dying and restarting.
author: philh
title: Dastardly Shapes
comments: Couldn't play it, only have Windows available... :(
I'm sympathetic to a fellow Linux fan, but you should really at least say that you're using SFML in the readme. :-)
Good point. I've updated the notes.
Had to compile it myself since you linked with SFML 1.6 and the version in Ubuntu is 1.5, but that's not your fault.
Enemies should probably stay within the gameplay area. Possibly dead enemies should too.
Time doesn't reset when you die.
Supporting WASD as well as arrows would be nice. Collision could stand to be a little more forgiving, both on enemies against the player and on bullets against the enemies.
A life system would make it less frustrating. One small screwup will send me all the way back to round 1 so I've only got as far as round 3 with the different yellow enemies.
Would love to rate this, but cannot for reasons I am sure you are aware of. Would you accept a hug instead? :P
Have built for windows and bundled along with what I think is all the required libraries.
Draknek - Thanks for the time thing; I've fixed that. The rest are good points that I would have liked to implement given more time.
Ali - you should be able to play now, but hugs are always welcome.
Covenant - you also should be able to play now. :)

description:
(Disclaimer: This is a long game, I decided to make a whole RPG with a beginning, middle and end. As a result I have been unable to test it thoroughly enough so I cannot guarantee that winning the game with the current set of rules is feasable. Also there's no save feature, which is necessary for such a long game. I hope to make a Jam version with this in.)
DAREMON - A Pokemon Spoof
-Overworld controls-
Arrow keys - move
Space/return - confirm/look/talk
-Battle controls-
Mouse driven.
You can carry one Daremon at a time. To get a better one, find a wild one and try to capture it. The weaker the Daremon the higher chance of capture!
Good luck!
author: Fiona
title: Daremon
comments: First the compliments. I love the creature designs, the game was really cute and funny, and the music was really good too. Three tunes made in that short a period was enough variety so none of them got old either. Also, the LD community cameos that I noticed made me laugh too.

Now the criticisms. The game's pretty unbalanced. Either everyone's attack is too high or everyone's defense is abysmal, but I could never weaken a Daremon enough to catch it, I'd just end up OHKOing them, so I went through the whole game with Spork. Also Level 13 Pixees would OHKO me at like level 30.
And also after you become an Elite, is that the end of the game? I got congratulated but I didn't get a THE END or anything.
Overall though I liked it. Really impressive and ambitious effort, and it's got a lot of charm. :]

I just started, and a lot of little things are bothering me. game uses Arrows, Enter, and Mouse. There is no comfortable way to fit your hands to these keys. WASD [any key near WASD] and mouse would be way more to my taste. Or even WASD ENTER nomouse

One hits everywhere, and things always get away. Captures seem to be very unlikely on creatures at full health, and weakenign them is harder still. Anyways, Either enemy 1 hits me, or I 1 hit it. There is very little concept of weakening
Music is cool, but sound effects are really annoying. That victory noise bothers me a lot.
""There is no comfortable way to fit your hands to these keys.""
unless your left handed like me :) but yea I always try to include both sides of the keyboard for that reason
Even though I gave up at the first town, I have to say it was pretty fun(ny). The spork alone makes it a game everybody needs to play.
The biggest problem with the game was the almost guaranteed one hit KO, as mentioned above.

The musics are nice (although the victory one is quickly annoying), the creatures are funny and all, but the keybindings are really annoying, the game is pretty unbalanced, and I had performance issues in all but the first place (however, I haven't a "real" 3D driver, that might be the only cause).

I really liked the humor, ("Now it's all over my shoes...", "Spork", etc), and the battle music made me want to dance. A lot of what I have to say has been said already. Annoying victory sound, unbalanced.

Though, I did notice strange black squares in the tiling every now and then that were consistent. I didn't play far enough in to figure out if that was a joke or not. But you have a very nice game there that seems to only need some tweaking. Good job.
I never played any pokemon game, but after trying this I guess I will. Well done (a little hard though)

description:
A simple little arcade game made with Flixel. One level, endless.
You have to dance around (cursor keys), flinging your partner (hit space) at other couples. Try to knock them down whilst avoiding being knocked down yourself.
Score combos. And watch out for waiters...
author: nyarla
title: dance dance dance
comments: This is very amusing. "Oh no, my interchangeable dance partner is about to get some wine! Stop him!"
This is kinda fun. The idea that your dance partner is your 'enemy' is a bit strange, but hey, I'll bite.
It'd be cool if your movement altered the trajectory of the dancers as well.
yeah, it's pretty loose on the theme.. ah well :)

i'll likely keep working on this, cos i quite like it. there are lots of things i want to add, especially much more varied enemy patterns and AI. and i'll change the graphics from dancers to some kind of weird sea anemones and fish or something.
I like it when non-violent social interactions are recontextualised like this.
Love the gameplay here, and the setting. Don't change it to be sea anemones, that would ruin some of the charm!

hehe. cheers guys.  Draknek - yeah I do like the silly dancing people, but I also envisage a more beautiful (rather than cute) style... the swirly movement patterns would suit underwater creatures I think. (it looks cool if you play long enough for there to be 10+ couples on screen..sort of hypnotic).    if i do that i'll preserve a dancing version too though. MUST ADD CONGA-LINE ENEMY.

GREAT game.   The sound effects really make this, I think.  It is pretty awesome, the aesthetic fits nicely.   I think you should be able to pick up multiple partners, but I've always thought that. :P
another vote for keeping it with people. Maybe add different dance moves as new 'weapons', and possibly the idea that flinging your partner off on the beat being more powerful...
Swing yer partner round and round...
Really bizarre, and I love it.  I see a lot of potential for expanding it.

Amusing concept, but I keep dying for some reason and only went up to when there are 3 "enemy" couples on screen. From the comments I gather that there might be something different afterwards... The single life thing is annoying. Doesn't fit the theme at all.

I loved it when I discovered that someone could steal my dance partner! There was surprising variety in that the flying glasses, drunken rages, and flinged partners were all potentially damaging. It was quirky and fun overall!

stqn - yeah, you can die suddenly, and it's sometimes hard to tell what killed you.. could be because of your dance parter rebounding off the side of the screen into you, or glasses flying after knocking down a waiter. I'm planning to make there be more than 1 life when I do more to this - haven't gotten round to it yet.

description:
Instructions are provided in game. The basic concept is that you have to kill as many enemies as possible, but you can't do it using your own body alone, as you're not strong enough! Press Spacebar to take over other people's bodies to keep fighting, and don't stop until you can't fight no more!
Known issues: If you miss taking over somebody's body, you'll need to restart the game!
*Punching animation won't show sometimes
*Enemies will punch each other
*If an enemy if above you, he will think you're at the same Y position as him
author: Blackduck
title: Change of Hearts
comments: good concept, but wasnt able to play ...
interesting concept, gameplay confusing but interesting once discovered
That's a really nifty fighting-game mechanic you've got there.
I like the concept/mechanic and the art style!
that was kind of odd gameplay. Nice graphic style, though!
Interesting concept and a nice graphical style. It did tend to devolve into a button mashathon at times however.

description:
This...
is...
Bouncing Bellyfloppers! Your mission is to constantly relocate our Mark IV Velocity Reversal Devices (or VRD's) in order to reflect the fat bellyflopping dudes that threaten to level our base of operations! The helicopters will come faster over time, so you may need to get creative...
Left click to select a trampoline, and then again to place it.
Have fun, and be sure to post your final wave and high score!
(Note: If this does not run for you on Windows, you may need the redistributable runtime. Try it and see!)
author: Entar
title: Bouncing Bellyfloppers
comments: That was pretty fun! Good at making me feel like I'm doing something incredibly slick when all I'm really doing is moving trampolines around :D
Very good... I'd do it a bit slower and add angles to the trampolines, for that extra difficulty... :)
An good variant on a missile command style game.  The early game was a bit slow, but once the helicopters really started rolling in it got pretty great.  The spring sfx was great.
Did feel like a bit of sideways velocity on the bellyfloppers would have added a lot of gameplay depth.  Even more so if it was aimable.
Nice game, nice use of the theme, nice graphics and annoying music. :-) Liked it very much.

description:
A simple shoot 'em up, in which the enemies shoot themselves up.
[Note: The larger the browser window, the lower the framerate, unfortunately. If you're having issues try making the window smaller and refreshing. If you're having severe framerate issues and are using Firefox, try switching to a WebKit-powered browser such as Chrome or Safari.]
By default, all shots are attracted to you. Use this to your advantage by letting them orbit back into the enemies. Move around to gain repulsion energy, then hit 'a' to switch and send bullets flying. The scoring metric is the time taken to clear the screen.
It's a difficult game. Take your time to get used to the mechanics, and try to have a store of repulsion energy for when you get surrounded. If you need precision, get a bullet to orbit and then switch to Repel when the shot lines up. For what it's worth, my high score hovers around 60s.
Attract is written in pure JavaScript, using the HTML5 Canvas APIs. This was my first time using JavaScript for anything other than simple web design stuff, so it's highly un-optimised and probably not too clean. If things start to slow down, try closing a few tabs or resizing the browser window. As always, I doubt this will work with Internet Explorer.
author: hturan
title: Attract
comments: This is a really appealing idea. I like how simple it is.

It does seem to run a bit slowly on the computer I'm playing on, but it's playable if I use a very small window. One other thing I noticed is that it's sometimes hard to tell exactly when the player is struck by a projectile. Some sort of impact effect would help to make it clearer.
Using my display's full resolution made the game freeze up after, I assume, a certain number of projectiles exist.

Yeah, the framerate is directly proportional to the number of bullets on the screen, and the number of bullets is directly proportional to the window size. I probably should have put more thought into performance.
yea shame about the frame rate. looks like a neat idea though!
runs great on my computer, game play was a little confusing the first try, but once you get the hang it's nice, still a little slow though.
It ran just fine here (after I switched to Chrome from Firefox). Nice idea, although I suck at playing it =P
That's a pretty cool concept. Kinda gets old quickly though, but it is still pretty cool to watch those laser beams go.

description:
Andrew The Angry Salmon is a puzzle platformer. Adrew shoots rockets with his dual bazookas. Aim your rockets to nuclear Jellos to explode the wobblers so sky high.
Use arrows to move and jump, X will shoot and R will reset the map. I tried to compose some tracks for the game but they came out so horrible that i didn't want to implement them. :S
author: T8000
title: Andrew The Angry Salmon
comments: Nice puzzles, made me think but weren't too hard, one of the games I've actually beaten so far. Art is fantastic and sound effects were well implemented.
Pov: Im glad you like them! :D
Thores: Thanks! Yeah i sould have made some more challenging maps in the end. :E

I really love this little game you've put together, not entirely sure on if the boom image fits with the style of the game though, but this is one of my favourite games of LD, it looks great, and the puzzles are well thought out, love it!

I enjoyed the game, the only thing I thought was unusual was to have unlimited shots since it is essentially a puzzler I would expect some limit. I did solve a few puzzle more through quick reflexes than brainpower. Overall quite good but a bit jarring how the game quits when you win the entire thing, maybe drop back to a menu or show an outro of some sort.
The art is great, and the game is quite fun, a nice mix of puzzle and twitch.  I'm not really convinced this really fits the theme.
But seriously, port it to flash and stick it on Kongregate.   Certainly a game I'd recommend to others.
Quanrian, yeah i was not too proud of some of the designs in the maps. Like the one you have to run as much as you can and trying to hit the falling jello. :P
Tenjou, ill probably port the game for android phones if i've got enough time. :o
5-stars on graphics. Looks gorgeous. It was a bit tedious for me, though. Really hard to see the connection to the theme.
Nice sound, would have liked to hear your music =)
"It was a bit tedious for me, though." Sorry to hear that. :S Could you be more specific? Was it the level design or the game mechanics or what? :o
I would be very interested to know.
Oh yeah for the music i need to learn a tracker composer program for the next ludum compo to make some neat chip beats. :P

description:
Use your mouse and keyboard to control your spaceship and beam up the floating alien spheres, and use their evil against them!
5 levels of increasing difficulty.
author: Danik
title: Alien Abduction of Aliens
comments: The base game works good. A ton of great background graphics. Unfortunately the gameplay itself turns quite boring after a while. There's no combo bonus from killing lots of aliens at the same time. There's only one enemy. I used an tractor beamed alien as a flail for a while, but that didn't hurt aliens either (would've been more fun than capture and shoot). Quite polished game overall.
For some reason it crashes when I click the left mouse button. Might be a problem with flash on my PC.
Andrew, yes, seems like the sound effects cause problems for some people. What java version do you have? Maybe I should make a no-sound version.
Loved the game, great work! I agree with Pokute that the gameplay could do with abit more depth, but when you only have 48 hours time is very limited!
Overall an excellent game, well done mate :)
Pokute, excellent idea! I think I will add that in a post-compo version.
great game :), nice level of difficulty curve also. although get a little boring eventually with just the same simple enemy,
Addictive gameplay! The backgrounds are soooo good.
It was annoying when I got hurt by humans behind the cloud, otherwise great game
Don't worry, it is working for me now, I don't know what fixed it.
This does work a lot like my game indeed, just less crazy and more polish. The graphics (especially the backgrounds) are lovely.

Good game.  The art was especially amazing.  It would be nice to be able to kill other enemies when you're pulling one in, by swinging it around.  As it is, if you missed the pull to you, you were disarmed for a while.  Also, if you start pulling in an enemy that dies, your tractor beam is stuck until you let it go. Only minor complaints, though!
I plan to make a post compo version, I have much planned for it, but it will take a while.

I can see from the playthrough that it could be fun, but unfortunately it's running way too slow on my computer, and the game is just boring. Otherwise, nice graphics and decent polish! I got no sound also, for some reason. Ah, that must be because your java thing uses OSS and not ALSA I guess... Completely stopping my music player did the trick.
well done enjoyed it. missing music though.

This was fun. I like how you can blow up bunches of aliens at once. Do you get any score bonus from that? I think that'd be cool. A couple of things that bugged me were that if you let go of your mouse button before you captured an alien, it would instead hit and damage you, and that it was sometimes kinda hard to catch an alien if you managed to get it into orbit. I also think the game could use some different types of aliens or maybe different weapons.
Big ups for rating 94% of the compo games, and by the looks of it, commenting on most of them too!

description:
Multicolored zombies, everywhere! And only one man is man enough to handle this! It's Mr Monocle! And he knows the art of fisticuffs!
"It's time to fisticuff and drink some tea, and I'm all out of tea!"
How to play the game:
Beat up zombie. Pick up zombie. Throw zombie at other zombie, because it deals more damage that way.
There's also boxes and barrels to pick up.
Eat food or die.
Green zombies are easiest. Blur are hardest. I let you figure out where the yellow zombies are in that list.
* Features fully animated images of me!
* Features nasal music, also by me
* Now also for windows computers! o/
Have fun!
EDIT: It appears that my OSX binary might have problems with OSX 10.5, so if you are using that OS I suggest you download the source instead. It will hopefully be fixed in a near future.
author: deps
title: Zombie Fisticuff Quarrel
comments: Windows version will be released tomorrow
Hahah, totally amazing stuff! :D Bi di di di Di ... di di ... di di...
Windows version is up! Have fun! :)
Punch the zombies!  Quite a solid 48-hour game.  The graphics do an excellent job of conveying meaning.  Sorry, no rating for sound because my VM that Gosu runs on doesn't do sound.
I don't see what it has to do with the theme, but I enjoyed the humor. :)
"Beat up zombie. Pick up zombie. Throw zombie at other zombie, because it deals more damage that way. "
You _can_ beat a blue zombie using your hands, but it's advicable to throw knocked down zombies on him. :)

A long time since I saw digitised people in a game; sort of missing that style now. Animations, although not using a lot of frames, were very effective and obviously modelled with great enthusiasm. Ultimately, I had endless fun beating up deps, then throwing deps at deps :)
this game makes me want to get gosu and code my next LD48 entry in sweet sweet ruby... although i think i'll have to settle for C
yes, fighting games are an invention but it's nice to pick them up and throw them at others... especially considering that they're all the same person

it gets a little repetitive but i didn't actually get bored whilist playing it, as i thought it wasn't going to get much harder i died... point for improvement would be multiple fighting moves, but seeing as you can throw barrels of explosive stuff i think i'll have to give you that 5th star

description:
Unarmed and Dangerous!
Written for Ludum Dare #18 (Theme: Enemies as Weapons)
By bluescrn (dave@bluescrn.net / www.bluescrn.net)
Controls
--------
Move: Arrow keys (or WASD)/ Note - you can jump 1-tile gaps by moving over them!
Restart Level: Space
Quit: Esc
To complete the level, you need to eliminate all nasty spiky enemies from the level... To do that, you'll have to
make them kill each other!
Notes
--------
- If you're missing a D3DX DLL, try downloading it here - http://www.toymaker.info/Games/html/d3dx_dlls.html
- Requires shader 2.0. May crash unpleasantly if you don't have support!
- Written in C++, D3D, FMOD, and was written with this basecode: http://www.bluescrn.net/LD48/LD48Base.zip
- It's terribly inefficient. Sorry. May set a new world record for number of single-poly draw calls in a  frame?
- The 'withoutbloom' .exe should run a bit faster on laptops/slow GPUs, but doesn't look as nice
- Yes, level 5 is possible
- Level 6 should be possible... but I've not done it myself yet(!)
- No, you can't complete level 7. If you get that far, you've won!
author: bluescrn
title: Unarmed and Dangerous
comments: I thought the idea was really good, but I found myself struggling with the controls. It's probably my fault, I can never get used to isometric controls, but I almost feel like a top-down view would have made it easier for me to play. As well, the view was small enough that I often didn't know I was jumping right into the way of an enemy, although that was also part of the strategy, so it's sort of a moot point, I suppose.
Couldn't get it to run, unfortunately.
I like the look of the game. For me the game itself was too challenging, i really could not get far. I still liked the idea you had there and everything seemed to work nicely. Great job overall!
Awesome!  Got to level 6 before I had to stop for some real-life stuff but I'm loving it so far and will return to it!
Fun game, but I found level 4 to be too big. I'd get reasonably far, but then I'd make a mistake and I'd have to start over from the beginning.
very good game. some music is missing :-)
Really nice game. I like the graphical style and the gameplay was quite fun, trying to work out how to get the enemies to collide with each other.
As usual, a brilliant game... :P Hate you, your stuff always looks so much better than mine! :)

Very good game concept but it's frustrating to have to restart from scratch after a mistake. I gave up after losing on time when I thought I had solved level 5. I think the time limit was a really bad idea. I don't want to have to do the same level again at full speed until I manage to get a good run without a stupid mistake to ruin it.
Make it more friendly instead of punishing and it would be great!

I really liked this, but it gets hard very quick. I stopped at level 6 because it just felt a bit too much for me. The visuals have a nice flare to them, as we've grown used to from your games. I think this could be a real hit if you eased the difficulty curve a bit.
Oh, and I also agree that the isometric controls take some getting used to. Might be nicer to have a head-on perspective

description:
Tested on Windows XP SP2.
Use WASD keys to move, mouse to aim.
The object is to lasso other enemies and throw them
as projectiles, in order to clear the screen.
To lasso, click and hold, while tracking the enemy with your
mouse. Then, keep holding whilst swinging. Aim and release.
Only 5 levels included. Hey, I ran out of time! :-)
IMPORTANT:
You will need to have the latest DirectX installed
http://www.microsoft.com/downloads/details.aspx?familyid=2da43d38-db71-4c1b-bc6a-9b6652cd92a3&displaylang=en
author: Kayamon
title: Tactics Lasso!
comments: Addendum: It appears that Level 4 may not actually be completable. <sigh>
Well, it's too late to do anything about it now I guess, once the deadline's passed. Wubbish.
When I try to run the game I get the error message "Error compiling shader." This is in Windows 7.
Sick lighting on that screenshot.  Unfortunately, I couldn't get it to play.
I get an error: "Error creating D3D device" :(
Screenshot looks amazing, but I get the "Error compiling shader" error (also Win7).
Error compiling shader... would be happy if you fix it, looks awesome!
So it turns out in order to run it, you need the latest version of DirectX installed.
You can get it from the link below. It's fairly painless.
I had tried including the D3DX DLLs myself in the zip, but it turns out this doesn't work. <sigh> Note to self, don't use D3DX ever again, even in a 48hr compo...
Fun concept. Unfortunately sometimes the enemy fell off the world but kept walking under it. Also the aiming is a little touchy.
Graphics are really nice, I like the high contrast shadows.
Downloaded the latest DirectX and still having the exact same problem. The screenshot looks so cool, I really want to play! :(
The DirectX install did fix my Error Compiling Shader problem.
Keeping the mouse on the guys was a little annoying.  Maybe if there was something to indicate how long you had to hold it on him for?

description: Help Swordfish Fisher-Fish eat some fish!
author: Fish
title: Swordfish Fisher
comments: Very tasty!  SFERNALD: This is a JAM entry and source code is NOT required.  Great game, I would have loved to hear some underwater sounds and fish eating sound effects.  Not sure if the second 3d window was required - it just got in the way.  Keep up the great work- well done.

description:
This game is full of random and odd things that are made to make you lol.
have fun!
(read the rread me)
author: pants
title: Sun Attack
comments: I like how the sun smiles when you die =)
Kind of funny, though I can only kill 1 enemy before the sun gets me.
That was hilarious!  I think you should tweak down the laser speed a little bit.
It's a pretty difficult game, but once you get the hang of it it is fun for a while.
I like the animation on the main character.

description:
Made in 14 hours.
All the info you need is either included in the readme, or is on the title screen.
There would have been more orb types had i started coding on Saturday, but this was made all on Sunday.
I'll probably add them in the future, but this is my competition build.
Have fun guys! Let me know what you think in the comments!
author: Nugsy
title: OrbIt
comments: what language did you use? It looks like some kind of basic.
nice idea with the grapple, got 760 :D well done
Nice responsive controls, a clever idea and it works well.
I would like to see more visual feedback when an orb blows up and when the player takes damage. Even a very simple effect would do.
It's nice that the player's ship, grapple and orb images were all made to fit together properly.
@sfernald I used BlitzMax (http://www.blitzbasic.com/Products/blitzmax.php). On second thought, i probably should have put that in the readme!

@localcoder I wanted to add a particle system, for explosions etc. But as i did the entire thing in one day i didn't really have time. In the future i'll probably release a post-compo build with a particle system, more orbs and possibly online highscores.
I don't know why the first sentence    looks   like   this lol.
Oh great, so the comment didn't even do what i wanted it to do that time. Haha, trolled by the comment formatting!

The concept is pretty good, but the mechanic ended up feeling a bit weak because it was rather too easy to just dodge between the orbs.  I think it would be better if the orbs were larger in comparison to the width of the playing field.
A solid entry. More variety and difficulty would certainly do wonders. Good job!

description: Java 1.5 is required, the game is played as an applet in a webpage.
author: Notch
title: Metagun
comments: Epic game, I hope you win this Notch!
Notch will win, I have no doubt about it.
Oops, the version up there had the debug spawn position set!
I've fixed it (within the time limit, note!)
This is simply fantastic, well done!
Megan is quite difficult to beat! All round a very good game, a great concept, and perfectly implemented. Happy to have played it!
Well made. Excellent take on the theme.
Some of the glass tile based kickback puzzles were infuriating, but other than that a solid platformer with a neat twist.
I like how you can run it as a standalone (I built from source).
I wonder if the focus on hats is a sign that he's selling Minecraft to Valve... and then the only new content will be hats.
Simon, he is making too much money to sell it to Valve. I recall Notch saying that Valve couldn't afford him. Anyway, the focus on hats (specifically fedoras) is because Notch really loves fedoras.
Awesome game, I love the use of the theme. Some hard levels, but I like the challenge. I hope you win Notch!
How to do the level with nearly only Tnt?

This game is so bizarre and unfriendly it is great. Almost every late-game challenge feels like you only won by abusing the system, by coercing unwilling game elements to unintentionally do your bidding. After using a minigun that shoots midgets to rocket-jump upward, then absorb dozens of bullets by grabbing your hat several times in a row, you will forget what 'enemies' and 'weapons' and 'hit points' in videogames should and should not be.
I have to mark it down a bit, though, because the end boss made the controls become erratic and unreliable, then, after several minutes, caused my browser to crash. Tsk, tsk.
This game was incredibly hard, but also incredibly fun. L summed it up fantastically.
Really cool take on the theme and a really fun and addictive game. Hard, but in a very good way.
Great game, it's orginal, fun and challenging, I hope you win.
Good job notch, the game was ridiculously hard. I loved it.
OK, in before dock telling everyone that apparently i'm a troll (the word is critic, dammit), and no this isn't my complete commentary thing so, uh:

Here's what I struggle with: The glass shooter parts are a pain in the butt, and the final boss appears to make its difficulty from making you lag enough that it doesn't realise you've pressed the X key. Got that out of the way.
I like the concept of shooting enemies out of your gun, and the recoil you get from the machine-gun-gun is quite nifty, although the gameplay appears to shift once you do that.
I also like the interaction with the hats, and that you can be countably awesome by wearing more than one at the same time.
From what I gather, this was an experiment which was done quite extensively, although some of it is a bit weird.
Also, L's comment (I haven't voted on this yet).

The graphics are wonderful. The game play and mechanics are so-so. The level design is not that great. The level with conveyer belts all by themselves? Unnecessary. Everyone's seen a conveyer belt before and knows how it works, we don't need to be spoon fed what they are.

Ultimately there are a lot of "hey look what I can make the game do" levels, and not many with clever or interesting puzzles. There were some decent ones, such as the one where you use the companion block to get to the top, but most levels were just keep spamming run/jump/shoot until you somehow survive by chance.
The level transitions are also quite buggy, I found it incredibly difficult to jump up through a level and then boost as the controls seize up momentarily.
Very Good Game, I hope you will win Notch ! Just one thing : the title graphique is ... bad. It don't make us want to play. But the game is good :p
Unbelievable that you pulled this off in 48h! The level deign i evil, some levels were extremely frustrating. Took me almost an hour to finish. ;D
Unfortunately unplayable here due to input lag and jerkiness :-/

Took me 30mins to complete and some area's are frustrating. Controls seemed a bit iffy in some areas such as trying to fly  but gameplay was very unique and interesting. If people were able to create their own maps it could become quite interesting.
Whilst there was an impressive amount of features for the timeframe I'm left feeling that a smaller but more polished set of mechanics would have felt significantly better.
I may simply be biased slightly for having ended my (previously only mildly frustrating) playthrough early by getting irrevocably and unfairly stuck in a wall.
Wow! You built an awesome amount of stuff in the allotted time and it was enough fun to keep me coming back even after I nearly quite in frustration (finished eventually)!
Controls are a bit annoying, but for the rest great game.

description:
Fistful of Beef is a game developed by the LOVE community, using the LOVE game development framework. The objective of the game is to destroy all cattle by catching a bull with your lasso, swinging it around you and smashing all the blasted bovine to bits!
The game should be playable for Windows, Linux and OS X. The .love/source file can be used if you have LOVE 0.6.2 installed. In case one of the builds don't work for you, you could try that.
author: Tommy Brunn
title: Fistful of Beef
comments: I love this game. Great job. Fun to play. Great music too.

description:
You play as a firefighter, fighting his greatest enemy...  Fire (You didn't see that coming?).  His weapon of choice?  Fire (Again, really I thought you'd get that).
The full title was given by my 4 year old daughter:
Fire, fire, where you are, I'm going to fight you with a fire department
Use wasd or arrows to move.  Move and click the mouse to set fires.  Use these fires to burn away fuel from the expanding wild fires.  There's also a nice surprise in there that fits all too well ;)
Note: There's a bug with the deltaT between levels, so to minimize its impact, make sure that you're not moving when a level ends.  I'll see if I can fix the library which causes it when I get home tonight.
Edit: I think I got it.  The original (bad) version can be found here:
http://code.bluedinosaurs.com/open/LD%2018%20-%20Jonny%20D%20-%20Fire%20Fire%20Where%20You%20Are%20-%20bad.zip
Everything is the same except for that game-crippling bug.
author: Jonny D

downloads.Windows: http://code.bluedinosaurs.com/open/LD 18 - Jonny D - Fire Fire Where You Are.zip
downloads.Linux: http://code.bluedinosaurs.com/open/LD 18 - Jonny D - Fire Fire Where You Are.zip

title: Fire, Fire, Where You Are
comments: Seems that on level 2 I am stuck in the water and it's difficult to move and maybe impossible to reach the land.
Ugh.  It seems kinda random, but sometimes the player or fire positions get messed up.  You should be able to try again and it might work.
The nature of bugs:  They don't make any sense!  I'll see about fixing this (and finishing the Gimp terrain filtering) in a post-compo version.
Had some trouble controlling the fire... most of the time, my mouse wouldn't start a fire, no matter if I pressed it or clicked it... :(
Were you trying it on fresh grass?  Fires won't start on burnt terrain.

Good use of theme, plus an original gameplay mechanic (I don't think I've ever seen a controlled-burn game before).  Could have benefited from sound, front-end menus and/or better flow. The art was good, and the fire effect was top-notch (although the grass is just a teensy bit on the bland side).
Five stars awarded under 'community' for taking part in a meetup and making a video of the event.
Overall, I'm awarding this four stars.  It's not perfect, but it is fun, and it has loads of potential.

I think this is a great idea, and a really creative use of the theme. To be honest, while I think the basic idea is totally sound, I think the game would benefit from having a bit more depth. I liked some of the later levels where I had to prioritize and make more decisions about where to put controlled burns. Those were the most fun parts of the game for me.
I wonder if it might be fun to allow controlled burns to get out of hand sometimes- perhaps they get too hot if we keep the mouse in one spot for too long? :D
It could add a bit of a risk / reward mechanic. Holding the mouse down would make areas darker, and thus more fireproof, but it would also require a bit of caution.
Anyway congratulations for finishing. Nice idea. I'd love to see more firefighting games, this mechanic seems like it's got a lot of potential.

Haha, I kept on accidentally setting the houses (and myself) on fire.  This game reminds me of a story my mum used to tell about how she 100% genuinely believed that firemen went round setting alight to peoples houses when she was young.
I love the full title, and the solid fire simulation.  Oh, and props for recovering from catastrophic source faliure (next time, version control! ;)
The controls are a little less lovable.

Did like the concept a great deal, though I found it too hard to exactly place my fires so they blocked the onslaught (I felt that once I had worked out where to place them, it shouldn't be a work of extreme precision to actually block off an area).
Nice original use of the theme and pretty too.

description:
Apologies for the scrappiness of the artwork, and also the lack of spell checking and proof reading... I just got it finished in time! ^o^ (The chances of me redrawing the backgrounds one day is quite high. I only had 10 minutes for each one.)
Silly piece of crap I made using RenPy.
author: bentosmile
title: Enemy of the Solid State
comments: I love the art!  The background painting is superb, I love how it is black and white and has such nice perspective.  You are too hard on yourself, it looks really great.
Great art as usual. I dig the pixelated transitions. Reminds me of the good ol' days. I made sure to play some music while I GAMED.

This was fantastic!  I played all the way through to the end, and had lots of fun. The characters were very fun and had excellent dialogue, and the whole game feels remarkably well fleshed out for a 72 hour game. Great ending too, congratulations!
Quite astonishing what you achieved in this space of time.  I'm really in love with the world you've created here, both visually and through the text.  Very funny in places, too.
I need to play a couple more times to get the full gist of it, but my first run was great.

description:
Click once to give the screen focus, then use the arrow keys to move.
Your mission is to travel down and to the right until you escape from the caverns into the unfinished part of the world.
Tools:
Actionscript, musagi, Paint.NET, Audacity.
author: localcoder
title: Cave Flyer (green)
comments: Hmmm... It seems as if you introduce the game's concepts in the opposite order that they ought. Ideally you'd first introduce evading small foes, then evading big foes, then the interplay between small and big foes, finishing by a large conflict between small and big foes.

The 'size = health' thing is an effective design decision, I will say. I'm also grateful that you didn't focus too much on it - for instance, by making the player take damage to pass through a small gap.

I really liked the 'size = health' thing, but it took me a while to figure it out (in the meantime i was wondering if i was invincible). Graphics were simple but had a nice, cohesive style which I really enjoyed.
It was a bit wierd that I seemed to go slower vertically than horizontally - it meant that I constnatly had to try and move left and right to avoid enemies.
It was interesting to have to lose some health along some of the routes, or to make it easier to get past some of the blocks.

Liked the Tron style a lot and the use of size-for-health (and the way that integrated with the navigation though smaller places; unlike the other reviewer, I felt this could have been more used). Not sure the theme was used as well as it might have, but I greatly enjoyed exploring the neon caves.
Graphics for the game and the mini-map are very different styles which is a bit weird.
BG music is nice and unintrusive.

I didn't really understand what the goal of the game was. Also I got stuck in a narrow passage because both ends were blocked by enemies. I liked that your health would recharge once you got away from enemies.
Nice job.. I managed to escape while only dieing a few times. I'm glad you coded checkpoints in!

description:
Here is my final entry, broken as it might be.
You are Brian Inajar the Brain In A Jar (hilarious!)
The object of the game is to kill the VIP in each level ('V' guy).
To do this you take over his body and use your psychic "Kill" command!
Some commands have a mental requirement which means you can't use it without weakening the mind of the host.
When you have selected a command you can see the area which will react to you using the command.
Controls:
Mouse to guide your psychic projection
Move into a body to take it over.
Right-click to exit bodies.
Left-click to select commands, and left-click again to use it.
Also you can't restart a level. It's broken :)
Notes for compiling:
I chose to be annoying and use a custom font. I included it with the source :O
Notes for huge file sizes:
Sorry...
author: WilTwin
title: Brain In A Jar
comments: I liked the idea, its a shame you could not make more maps. :S
Oof. Not being able to restart is definitely a problem.
I had some problems with that and about 1 hour after the deadline, I realized how easily I could have done it -.-. It's really just a 2-3 extra lines :P
Please do not use installers. Installing 50+ games with installers is just not without unlimited amount of time.
I'd rather not install anything either (under Linux/Wine here.)
Am I allowed to add a new file?
Nice idea, fairly good start of something.
Its an XNA project. I used the exe in the source download (src/ld18game/ld18game/bin/x86/debug/) to not have to use the installer.

description:
This is a Jam submission. We had about 10 (!) people working on it, with various levels of commitment. Integrated level editor, rotationally-symmetric physics, gotta-catch-'em-all gameplay, over SEVEN levels to play, speedrun mode, custom raytraced lighting... needless to say this game is "magnificent."
This game is winnable without cheating, but good luck. :)
Sequel to the smash hit "Bouncecrab" from LD17.
Linux port is possible and may be forthcoming.

author: Tom 7
title: Bouncecrab 2: Friends as Anemones

description:
We had a lot of fun creating this so hope you enjoy it. It's not as polished as I'd have liked and theres plenty of bugs and stuff missing that we're aware of, but we're submitting anyway :)
We will be continuing development during the week and until we get it to the point we originally envisioned for the project.
OBJECTIVE:
There is only one level and the aim of the game is to capture the enemies and throw them at other enemies to kill them. The game never ends so your aim is to try get the highest score without dying.
NOTE:
Some machines will require the MC VC++ 2010 x86 Redist and possibly the DirectX June 2010 Redist. I hope this doesn't discourage anyone from trying the game :) Links to the redist are in the readme file.
author: Firefly
title: Big Boy Goes To Fun Place
comments: Wow, I get 2700 fps! The game does feel like it's going too fast. In the end I got stuck off screen at the right.
Anyway, I like the graphics and the music.

Great title screen and music!  Game itself was rather confusing and I had to install MC VC++ 2010 x86 Redist just to get it to run, unfortunately.  The jump is useless and only jumps a few pixels, but I couldn't work out if it's a bug or something?

description:
Use your enemies' heads to score and kill more enemies.
I make code and music, you can't expect me to be good at graphics too. ;)
author: JDruid
title: Basketball girl
comments: How delightfully weird! And the music is quite catchy, too.

If it was a little longer, it would have been great. It took a bit of getting used to how weird it was, but after that I quite enjoyed it. The music was nice. It could have used some more sound effects, and those that were present could have been better. All in all it was a pretty decent little game.
Strange, gruesome, and interesting all at the same time.
A bit weird (and weird is good)... Was fun the first 3 or 4 levels, then it became tiring...
Pretty cool, not sure if it was intentional but this sort of thing seems to happen alot --> http://mikecann.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2010/08/ScreenHunter_01-Aug.-24-21.46.jpg
well done. I love the idea of throwing heads into a basket.
ok, i know you're in #mod_shrine and i know that you managed to beat coda so i'm going to give this one a crack
first thing i have to say is split your code into logic and graphics, that way your game can run at a good speed on pretty much any platform, you're working with python so it's not incredibly fast
ok, now playing at what i think is full rate, took a while but i eventually fixed up all but a few things
righty, let's get this show on the road
i am definitely aware that there's more that can be done with respect to innovation, such as switches & stuff, but having said that it's an interesting and unexpected concept, so here, have 5 stars
quite fun, pity it's a bit slow even at full speed BUT simply speeding it up might not be a good idea as it's still quite tricky
fairly nonstandard standard implementation of the theme and that's a good thing
graphics looks like an ms paint job BUT they're used quite well and quite frankly i really don't care too much about graphics
...just kidding, it's brilliant, just needs a bit more sound to give it that extra oomph
humour can be felt throughout the game so have a few stars
overall, recommended for people who don't have such weak necks
